[03:10:00.0000] <roc>
if we want an good baseline video codec

[03:10:01.0000] <roc>
and the barrier is the choices made by device manufacturers and their hardware suppliers

[03:10:02.0000] <roc>
and their decisions are purely economic

[03:11:00.0000] <hsivonen>
how varied are the DSPs used in contemporary handhelds?

[03:11:01.0000] <roc>
then the only practical way forward is to encourage the proliferation of content in an unencumbered codec, to tip that economic balance

[03:12:00.0000] <roc>
so it seems to me that everyone who's interested in having a good baseline video codec should be encouraging that

[03:13:00.0000] <roc>
including by supporting Theora wherever the device constraints do not apply

[08:16:00.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: It gives the absolute URL

[08:19:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:19:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Hixie?

[08:20:00.0000] <annevk2>

[08:20:01.0000] <annevk2>

[08:25:00.0000] <annevk2>

[08:26:00.0000] <annevk2>

[08:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
attribute [ReflectURL] DOMString src;

[08:29:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
[[

[08:29:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
This indicates that the src DOM attribute reflects a content attribute  

[08:29:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
named src, but that the result is a completed URL, not the raw  

[08:29:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
attribute value:

[08:29:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
]]

[08:29:06.0000] <annevk2>
I'd think you want [Reflect=URL]

[08:30:00.0000] <annevk2>
'cause all "reflect" thingies have something in common, but some have specific types

[08:31:00.0000] <annevk2>
(e.g. they all create a new content attribute if none exists)

[08:31:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
annevk2: I guess they didn't do it that way maybe because of  [Reflect=URL] would imply there's a content attribute named "URL"

[08:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
because they're also doing, attribute [Reflect=class] DOMString className;

[20:28:01.0000] <roc>

[20:29:01.0000] <sayrer>

[20:29:05.0000] <roc>

[20:30:00.0000] <sayrer>

[20:30:01.0000] <roc>
no

[20:30:02.0000] <sayrer>
ok

[20:30:03.0000] <roc>

[20:30:04.0000] <roc>

[20:30:05.0000] <roc>

[20:30:06.0000] <roc>
and it changes a lot

[20:30:07.0000] <sayrer>

[19:13:00.0000] <sinuhe>

[19:19:00.0000] <T-->
sinuhe, I'm not authorative in this regard, just reporting my gut instinct. kbd for communicating with the computer, samp for content, the computer reports back and var is orthogonal to both of them, meaning usable whenever one needs something variable or an example.

[04:04:01.0000] <Philip`>

[05:05:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and VP3 appeared around the same time (in fact I believe it was a rejected candidate for MPEG-4 Part 2 video, the pre-H.264 MPEG-4 video codec)

[05:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if independent implementations are not allowed or must pay, then I would find that more of a problem from the spec POV than for Apple specifically (since the reference implementation is BSD-licensed)

[05:11:00.0000] <Lachy>
wikipedia says that On2 released the codec under an open source licence and disclaimed all rights to their patent, citing this licence http://trac.xiph.org/browser/branches/vp32/vp32/VP32_license.txt

[05:11:01.0000] <doublec>
"VP3 allows for the highest quality video, at the lowest possible data rates while still retaining the video's full frame-rate. The result is a clear 320x240 video that can be expanded to a full-screen 640x480 resolution. The power of this codec has been validated by the fact that it has been licensed by both RealNetworks and Apple for their internet video players."

[05:11:02.0000] <othermaciej>
that patent doesn't actually disclaim all rights (it is one of the two I linked)

[05:11:03.0000] <doublec>

[05:12:00.0000] <Lachy>

[05:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the later patent disclaimer (not license) seems limited to derivative works, but doesn't have the field-of-use restriction

[05:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[14:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
how could you do it server-side?

[14:06:02.0000] <Hixie>

[14:06:03.0000] <Hixie>

[14:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
HTML5 parser speed isn't important - just parse once per revision, then cache it as XML

[14:07:01.0000] <Lachy>

[14:08:00.0000] <Lachy>

[14:00:04.0000] <tantek>
gnsedders - I disagree - specifically, Shelley's recent message: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Jul/0152.html has a good tone and a reasonable listing of concerns with the methodology of analysis of summary. At a minimum, those concerns could (should) be documented on a wiki page, and then addressed.

[14:01:00.0000] <sayrer_>
jgraham: well, we are stuck if you are wed to making the attributes lack of success result in a conformance error

[14:02:00.0000] <tantek>
gsnedders - in addition, framing the debate as "from either side" unnecessarily harms the ability for all sides to make scientific progress on various possibilities by polarizing the issue.

[14:03:00.0000] <tantek>
gsnedders, you're right about being stuck in circles due to it being discussed in email. if you capture the issues and follow-ups in a wiki page, it becomes much easier to represent loops and duplicates (via hyperlinks) than in email.

[14:04:00.0000] <gsnedders>
tantek: I think we went through stuff like what Shelley's message is about at TPAC last year with PF, though, and within a few weeks the arguments were back to what they were before that meeting

[14:04:01.0000] <tantek>
gsnedders - so why weren't those points recorded on a wiki then so they could be properly assessed? (rather than being repeated in email)

[14:07:00.0000] <tantek>
jgraham - Wikipedia has had to deal with far worse conflicts than this, by recording multiple points of view (and arguments for/against), and has done so. So I disagree with your assessment that it is "unlikely [to] go down well" - offering Wikipedia conflict documentation as evidence.

[14:07:01.0000] <sayrer_>

[14:07:02.0000] <sayrer_>

[14:09:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[14:09:03.0000] <sayrer_>

[14:10:01.0000] <jgraham>

[14:11:01.0000] <sayrer_>

[14:12:00.0000] <jgraham>
sayrer_: It increases the language surface that authors will encounter. There is value in "there whould be one and only one obvious way to do it"

[14:13:00.0000] <sayrer_>
that is a very subjective area to venture into, but I agree it is a legitimate concern

[14:13:01.0000] <tantek>
jgraham - that wiki page certainly has a lot of good documentation, but does little to address follow-ups of the points made.

[14:15:00.0000] <tantek>
jgraham - I agree with you about minimizing the "language surface that authors will encounter" - I've been referring to that as the principle of minimal vocabulary and have documented it as a microformats design principle: http://microformats.org/wiki/minimal-vocabulary

[14:16:00.0000] <tantek>
in short, lower cognitive load which greatly helps ease of use (for authors and developers)

[14:17:00.0000] <sayrer_>
a counter example might be presentational elements

[14:18:00.0000] <sayrer_>
since those let authors do simple formatting without learning CSS

[16:17:00.0000] <hober>
pedantic correction: it's {{Citation needed}}

[16:17:01.0000] <tantek>
regarding "PFWG has consensus on the idea that summary="" is successful" - it is better (more scientific) to document data/opinions, even bad data / opinions, and debunk it, than not to document it at all.

[16:17:02.0000] <Lachy>
hober, it's it {{cite}} ?

[16:18:00.0000] <Lachy>
s/it's/Isn't/

[16:18:01.0000] <tantek>
debunk *them* (them being the opinions as it were, not the people)

[16:18:02.0000] <tantek>
if necesary, label opinions as "appeal to authority", or "based on personal anecdote" etc., whatever you think is the appropriate critique.

[16:19:00.0000] <tantek>
because even data based on personal anecdote is better than no data.

[16:19:01.0000] <tantek>
it just has be considered with the appropriate weight relative to other kinds of data (data on studies of a hundred websites for example)

[16:23:00.0000] <Lachy>

[16:26:00.0000] <tantek>

[20:40:00.0000] <jwalden>
which doesn't seem likely to happen given the enormity of the prerequisite tasks, but is not entirely unlikely

[21:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
roc: well, a lot of the arguments sicking makes seem to apply equally to ignoring mozilla's preference and requiring support for the sql database api

[21:04:00.0000] <roc>
The arguments seem completely different to me

[21:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
in each case, the argument for inclusion would be to promote interoperability by exerting market pressure on holdouts

[21:05:01.0000] <roc>
but the reasons for people holding out are completely different

[21:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so your Mozilla's reasons for holding out are valid but Apple's are not?

[21:06:01.0000] <roc>
Modulo my limited understanding of Apple's reasons --- yes.

[21:08:00.0000] <roc>
if Web SQL was the only plausible solution for structured client-side storage, I'm sure we'd just bite the bullet and do it.

[21:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so existence of plausible (though not yet materialized) alternatives justifies holding out, in a way that specs should accomodate?

[21:13:00.0000] <roc>
depends on what you mean by "materialized"

[21:13:01.0000] <roc>
http://hg.toolness.com/browser-couch/raw-file/blog-post/index.html

[21:14:00.0000] <roc>
there are many other differences between the two situations

[21:14:01.0000] <Hixie>
fundamentally, i don't think i should be in the business of saying that apple's reasons are less good than mozilla's reasons

[21:14:02.0000] <Hixie>
in particular, not when it won't make any difference anyway

[21:14:03.0000] <Hixie>
as in this case

[21:15:00.0000] <roc>
e.g., only one browser implements Web SQL currently, so there's no interop to speak of, whereas we have three browsers with demoed or shipping Theora implementations, one of which is actually different code

[21:15:01.0000] <roc>
there's the issue of Web SQL not having a real spec

[21:15:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Right now we have 1 browser shipping it and 2 that have publicly committed to doing so

[21:15:03.0000] <roc>
Has Opera committed to it?

[21:15:04.0000] <othermaciej>
vs for Theora, 2 browsers shipping and 1 publicly committed

[21:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Opera has said they will do it

[21:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
(websql will have a real spec after html5 is in last call, assuming no better alternatives surface -- i'll write it myself if i have to :-) )

[21:16:02.0000] <roc>
othermaciej: OK, that strengthens the case for Web SQL a bit.

[21:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Mozilla is entitled to wait and see what happens, even if I would prefer you did implement Web SQL

[21:17:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that's why I proposed splitting it from the rest of the Web Storage spec

[21:17:02.0000] <roc>
I doubt we'll see an independent implementation of SQLite's SQL dialect, though, which remains a worry

[21:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
i think mozilla's concerns with websql are perfectly valid

[21:17:04.0000] <Hixie>
i think apple's concerns with theora are valid too

[21:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
insofar as mozilla thinks their concerns are valid, and apple thinks their concerns are valid

[21:18:01.0000] <othermaciej>
fwiw Apple is doing a new round of research on the matter

[21:18:02.0000] <roc>
I don't think we should shy away from making value judgements about peoples' concerns

[21:18:03.0000] <roc>
people have unreasonable concerns sometimes

[21:18:04.0000] <roc>
I know it can sound arrogant

[21:18:05.0000] <Hixie>
that's a very dangerous path to go down, imho

[21:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
and not one that leads to productive cooperation

[21:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
what would you do if i said that mozilla's concerns re websql weren't valid?

[21:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
i doubt you would really appreciate it

[21:19:03.0000] <roc>
We'd argue about it

[21:19:04.0000] <roc>
in the past I've had a lot of concerns that you have assuaged in one way or another

[21:20:00.0000] <roc>
I don't think I personally, or Mozilla in general, am immune to unrealistic or overblown concerns

[21:21:00.0000] <roc>
putting them on an untouchable pedestal is itself dangerous

[21:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm talking specifically about "we won't implement X" feedback

[21:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
for more nuanced feedback, things are more complex

[21:21:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the only thing anyone has done to assuage Apple's concerns (or Google's) about Theora is to say they shouldn't count or imply that they are not on the level

[21:21:04.0000] <roc>
Mozilla has not said "we won't implement SQL"

[21:22:00.0000] <roc>
at least, I don't think we have

[21:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
not quite as explicitly as apple has said it about theora, i'll grant you

[21:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
anyway, my point was just that sicking's comments seemed to be dangerously close to saying "ignore apple", which i don't think it would be appropriate for me to do, as i think it would set a precedent for ignoring any vendor whose feedback isn't convenient.

[21:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
which could be mozilla, e.g. as with websql

[21:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm just trying to treat everyone fairly :-)

[21:24:01.0000] <roc>

[21:24:02.0000] <roc>

[21:24:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:24:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:28:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:28:04.0000] <roc>

[21:28:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:28:06.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:28:07.0000] <roc>
what sort of limit?

[21:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:29:01.0000] <roc>
ok

[21:30:00.0000] <roc>

[21:30:01.0000] <roc>

[21:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[07:39:00.0000] <karlcow>

[07:39:01.0000] <Philip`>

[07:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
"switching from HTML to XHTML was the perfect catharsis to leave behind not only the old syntax, but more important the old habits and practices of building a webpage"

[07:41:01.0000] <karlcow>

[07:41:02.0000] <karlcow>
Philip`: yep, it helped people to look at the language in a different way.

[07:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:42:01.0000] <karlcow>

[07:43:00.0000] <karlcow>

[07:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
"[XHTML] taught a generation of developers what good code should or could look like. It was something that was always possible in HTML4 but XHTML1 helped train people to be more thoughtful and careful with their code. And in that sense, I think it was a success."

[07:44:01.0000] <Lachy>
It seems that Zeldman's point is that promoting XHTML was good because he used it as a hook for the idea of promoting better semantics and structure, but that unfortuately gave rise to the myth that XHTML is somehow more semantic than HTML.

[07:44:02.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Myths aren't necessarily bad

[07:44:03.0000] <karlcow>

[07:44:04.0000] <Lachy>

[07:45:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:45:01.0000] <jgraham>

[07:46:00.0000] <Lachy>

[07:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
karlcow, in that table, for some of the things like Unquoted Attributes and Attribute minimisation, the cells in the XHTML column say "not allowed" accompanied by an example.  At first, it wasn't clear to me what about the example wasn't allowed.

[07:57:01.0000] <Lachy>
Then I realised that it was meant as an example of what is allowed in XHTML. It would be nice to find a way to make that clearer

[07:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Seems like division of labour - some people spend years learning all the subtleties of markup syntaxes, and then provide recommendations which can be followed by people who don't want to waste time repeating that whole learning exercise needlessly, and those recommendations necessarily have to summarise and condense and ignore some issues so they can be understood more readily

[07:59:01.0000] <Lachy>
and I object to you using <p class=sloppy> as an HTML example of unquoted attributes. Saying it's sloppy seems to convey that it is somehow bad, even though it's a perfectly valid technique

[08:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and hopefully the people providing the recommendations can minimise the harm caused by misinterpretation of the truth)

[08:00:01.0000] <Lachy>
I would prefer it if documents like this stayed more neutral on the debate about which syntax is better to use, and let authors make a more informed choice

[08:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and those experts would still be expected to justify their arguments in detail if someone asked them about it, so they're not expecting people to blindly rely on their expert status)

[08:01:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: There is truth in that. In this case I dispute that "XHTML good, HTML bad" (which was roughly the message that many people got) is at the right level of simplicity

[08:03:00.0000] <Lachy>
the right message that should be conveyed to web developers is that HTML and XHTML are optimised for different requirements, and that authors should choose the one most appropriate for their needs

[08:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
If people think that quoating their attribute values and closing their tags helps them to write maintainable code then that's a decision that they should be free to make. We should have tools to help them enforce those coding standards. We shouldn't conflate that with pseudo-XHTML

[08:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
In most cases, given the current browser market, the right choice is generally HTML. But there are legitimate uses for XHTML when done right

[08:04:01.0000] <Lachy>
jgraham, indeed

[08:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: So it sounds like you agree with the general idea of lying to simple-minded developers, and just have a different view (than people promoting only-XHTML-is-semantic) of whether the harmful consequences of one particular simple lie are unpleasantly (and hopefully avoidably) high

[08:07:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: I agree that it shouldn't be necessary to know the full detail of the whole language to get started. I wouldn't haracterise that as "lying"

[08:07:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: "Not telling the truth", then? :-)

[08:08:00.0000] <jgraham>
(I also think that the language should be designed in such a way that it is easy to learn the full language)

[08:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Not really. "Not trying to present the full complexity of everything all at once but making it avaliable when necessary" sould be more like it

[08:09:01.0000] <jgraham>
*would

[08:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: (The full language is a simplification of reality devised by experts, who e.g. understand all the details of what <br /> means in SGML and XML and how it's implemented in browsers and why it was promoted instead of <br/> and how common all these things are, and choose to hide all those details and just recommend "you must do this or this")

[08:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: (so "learn[ing] the full language" just seems like another instance of following experts' recommendations without really understanding them)

[08:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: (and doesn't seem fundamentally different to other instances of the same thing, at higher levels than the markup language syntax)

[08:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: (I hope you don't ask me to clarify my argument since I've now forgotten what my argument was or whether I even had one)

[08:17:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: It seems like a big leap to go from "practitioners of the language should be knowledgeable enough to to make informed choices within the constraints imposed by the conformance criteria" to "there should be no conformance criteria since they represent arbitary limitations"

[08:17:01.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: It does

[08:17:02.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Who is suggesting the latter?

[08:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
(...in this discussion, i.e. ignoring sayrer :-p )

[08:22:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: It seemed like the logical conclusion of your argument that "learn[ing] the full language" just seems  like another instance of following experts'  recommendations without really understanding them

[08:22:01.0000] <Lachy>
I can't believe how many of my twitter followers have joined in the "campaign" to get me on the Australian version of Beauty and the Geek, despite me not being there to participate :-/

[08:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: My argument is that people should be able to follow experts' recommendations without really understanding them, and the experts should provide recommendations to optimise that behaviour

[08:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. by providing conformance criteria for the language, and providing simple marketing terms like "XHTML" or "AJAX" or "HTML5" to encourage people to adopt a whole platformful of goodness (while trying to minimise the harm from the simplifications)

[08:26:00.0000] <jgraham>
I agree with the first part, less so with the second

[08:26:01.0000] <jgraham>
(and of course with the thrd)

[08:28:00.0000] <beowulf>
web developers don't need to understand the sticks with which they beat each other with, but it helps

[08:30:00.0000] <nikto>
and then comes the Black Swan, and your 'web developers' that just follow guidelines and expert counseling are faced to understand the 'display' property and it's values, and how this affects rendering of DIVs, SPANs, and everything

[08:30:01.0000] <nikto>
so.. a nice learning path for the very deep details should be offered to them, imho

[08:31:00.0000] <nikto>
not to mention the difference it makes when in quirks mode, or when in stric mode, etc.

[16:12:03.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: arguably summary="" is useless because too many people have gotten it wrong already. :-)

[16:12:04.0000] <gavin_>
seems like we're mostly debating semantics :)

[16:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
worse than semantics

[16:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
psychology :-/

[16:13:02.0000] <gavin_>
maybe the validator can call them "conformant errors"

[16:13:03.0000] <Hixie>
hah

[16:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: so you'd be ok with the proposal i described, if we just made the downplayed errors into frowned-upon-but-ok? i.e. changed from "not serious errors" to "discouraged non-errors"?

[16:14:01.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, that depends on the ability of ATs being able to reliably filter out useless values, which we've been told they do, but been given no details about how

[16:14:02.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: yeah, that information would definitely help

[16:14:03.0000] <Lachy>
nor how reliable it is

[16:14:04.0000] <Hixie>
we really should do usability testing of this

[16:14:05.0000] <Hixie>
it's hard to do usability testing for AT users, though

[16:14:06.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe the validator should do like what the Yahoo and Google page speed tools do, giving each message a red/yellow/green severity and showing them in decreasing order of severity, so you can see which issues are the most worth fixing

[16:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
because you have to go to their setups, you can't just have them come in

[16:15:01.0000] <Lachy>

[16:15:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I think that would be a good improvement beyond even the summary="" issue

[16:15:03.0000] <Hixie>
from what i've seen of usability studies of AT users here at google, they don't. at least not the ones we found for our studies.

[16:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: and yes, I would be in favor of that proposal

[16:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: ok. i'll see what hsivonen thinks, and will see if i can find a way to phrase it that satisfies both the desire to keep these things as second-class citizens, and the desire to allow them to some extent.

[16:17:01.0000] <Lachy>
how is that different from the downplayed errors we already have in the spec?

[16:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
a document containing a downplayed error is nonconforming

[16:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
so maybe we should have conformance levels, conceptually like the WCAG accessibility levels?

[16:19:01.0000] <Philip`>
Sounds like it's going to be horrendously confusing to someone who just wants to be told whether their page is okay or not

[16:19:02.0000] <Lachy>
but then, that's getting closer to the idea of Strict/Transitional conformance

[16:22:00.0000] <gavin_>
Philip`: "good", "ok, with some problems" and "bad" doesn't seem that confusing

[16:23:00.0000] <gavin_>
but even with those three buckets there are going to be arguments as to what goes where

[16:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, my idea sucks. Don't listen to me.

[16:25:01.0000] <Dashiva>
"strict", "transitional", "invalid"

[16:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think "good with no warnings", "good with warnings" and "bad, there are some errors" are sensible states

[16:26:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that is what programmers get from compilers and such

[16:29:00.0000] <Lachy>
that seems reasonable. Though it still sucks having to settle for compromises like this just to stop the arguments.

[16:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
my personal point of view is that it's the right thing to do, not just a compromise

[16:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
because sometimes, there are things that are often but not universally bad, and the right treatment is a mandatory but nonfatal diagnostic

[16:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
some people will only care about error-free and take the warnings on a case-by-case basis, some will want their pages warning-free too

[16:31:00.0000] <Lachy>
I disagree, but fair enough

[16:31:01.0000] <Dashiva>
That's fair enough, I think the problem are the people who just see "Okay" and ignore the "but"

[16:31:02.0000] <Philip`>
The validator could let you specify -Werror and Wno-foo

[16:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
yes, the validator should be able to toggle warning classes and also optionally treat warnings as fatal

[16:31:04.0000] <Philip`>
(for all values of foo)

[16:31:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I personally would want to use it in that mode, I think

[16:32:00.0000] <Lachy>
othermaciej, are you suggesting this be applied to all attributes that are currently considered downplayed errors, or just to summary?

[16:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Lachy: Hixie proposed converting the whole "downplayed error" class into something warning-like (i.e. does not break conformance)

[16:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think having "error" and "warning" instead of "error" and "downplayed error" as the two classes of diagnostics makes sense

[16:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, i could reluctantly be convinced of that, i think

[16:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I haven't reviewed every current use of downplayed error, so I don't have an opinion on which should become nonfatal and which should be fatal

[16:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it would probably merit case-by-case review, since for some it may make sense to just convert them back to errors

[16:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
(i was reading a scifi story recently where people could run simulations of their mental processes on a computer, and at one point one of the characters is in a debate

[16:36:02.0000] <Hixie>
and he just ran 15,000 simulations of how the argument might play out with his simulated mental processes in "vm"s

[16:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
in 95% of cases he was convinced. so he just decided to assume he'd be convinced, and skip the 15 minutes discussion that would otherwise ensue.

[16:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
i find this a fascinating concept.)

[16:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(though sometimes it's important to know why you have been convinced)

[02:28:00.0000] <jgraham>
So "obsolete" is the new "deprecated"

[02:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
/me growls at bug 7089

[02:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
jgraham: it always has been, hasn't it?

[02:29:00.0000] <jgraham>
Well I mean "obsolete"+warning

[02:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
the big difference between Transitional and the warnings is that you don't ever see "Your document is conforming!" if you have warnings, you see "You document is conforming, but with warnings"

[02:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
with transitional, once you had the transitional doctype, you never again saw anything clearly telling you that you weren't strict

[02:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
at least, i reckon that's a difference

[02:30:02.0000] <jgraham>
Given how popular compiler warnings are I can't imagine it will make a big difference

[02:30:03.0000] <Hixie>
true

[02:30:04.0000] <Hixie>
oh well, we'll see

[02:30:05.0000] <Hixie>
there's not much on the list

[02:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: are you saying compiler warnings are popular, or unpopular?

[02:31:01.0000] <jgraham>
othermaciej: I assume they are popular because compiling software tends to give me so many of them ;)

[02:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
heh

[02:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
WebKit builds with -Werror (or equivalent) and with many optional warnings on

[02:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(although in MSVC we have to turn some off, because they are stupid)

[02:32:02.0000] <jgraham>
(In seriousness, I know that many projects have a zero-warnings policy but it hardly seems to be normal and in web-developert terms probably translates onto the people who would care about the strict/transitional distinction)

[02:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
for example, if you use a high enough warning level and don't silence this one specifically, MSVC will complain if you write if (intVariable) { something(); }

[02:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it wants you to say if (!!intVariable) { something(); }

[02:34:00.0000] <jgraham>
what's the difference?

[02:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
in generated code and actual effect? nothing

[02:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but for the former, it complains about an implicit conversion to bool

[02:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
and !!a isn't an implicit conversion?!

[02:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
(if (intVariable != 0) seems nicer to read)

[02:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and warns you that it may be slow, or something

[02:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not giving this as an example of a good warning!

[02:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
The Intel C++ Compiler has "info" (I think) messages, as well as errors and warnings, which say things like "order of argument evaluation is undefined" that aren't serious enough to be warnings

[02:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok bed time

[03:10:00.0000] <Lachy>

[03:11:00.0000] <Philip`>

[03:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me is interested since his font subsetting tools makes fonts that can't easily be reused outside the web (or outside the context where they were originally used), and wonders if that's considered a bad thing

[03:13:00.0000] <jgraham>

[03:13:01.0000] <jgraham>
s/testing/deployment/

[03:13:02.0000] <Lachy>
EOT places restrictions on what domains a font can be used on and expects browsers to enforce those restrictions.

[03:14:00.0000] <Lachy>
(I could be remembering that wrongly, but I know the font foundries have been pushing for a feature like that in one form or another)

[03:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you could e.g. tweak a TTF/OTF so that it works fine in web browsers but is kind of broken if used in many other applications, e.g. by setting the embedding bits or setting the font name to "", would that be considered harmful to the world?

[03:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
yes, because it imposes what could be considered to be a Technological Protection Measure on the font, and could be subject to anti-circumvention clauses of laws like the DMCA.

[03:25:01.0000] <Lachy>
It would be the font equivalent of the failed broadcast flag proposal

[03:27:00.0000] <Lachy>
also, that's one of the proposals that was discussed on www-style a long time ago

[03:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
and I recall someone from the Linux community saying that support for the flag would have to be integrated into the systems font handling, and thus wouldn't protect against other uses on the system anyway

[07:12:01.0000] <Lachy>

[07:15:00.0000] <karlcow>

[07:19:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: warnings don't need new UI code, so they are easier

[07:20:00.0000] <Lachy>

[07:21:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: downplayed errors would have counted towards making the result turn into invalid

[07:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: and the vision for downplayed errors was that they'd sort and collapse differently

[07:38:00.0000] <Lachy>
hsivonen, that sounds like little more than UI design decisions that aren't really affected by what the spec actually said.

[07:40:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: the non-UI effect is that the presence of one or more downplayed errors made the document invalid but the presence of normative warnings doesn't

[07:49:00.0000] <Lachy>
so it's a very fine line between "non-conforming, but ignorable errors" and "conforming, but with warnings"

[07:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
"non-conforming, but ignorable errors" wouldn't give you a badge

[07:52:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:35:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
ok

[08:35:02.0000] <sayrer__>
Lachy: sure

[08:36:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Lachy: I suspect sayrer__'s point is that they shouldn't be normative conformance criteria

[08:36:01.0000] <Lachy>
but then that wouldn't be very useful

[08:37:00.0000] <sayrer__>
useful for producing interoperable markup?

[08:38:00.0000] <Lachy>
sayrer__, while we could very easily get interoperability between implementations without any authoring conformance criteria, normative conformance criteria are essential to ensure conformance checkers are interoperable and to help authors write markup properly

[08:39:00.0000] <sayrer__>
you mean lint tools must produce the same result for all input?

[08:39:01.0000] <karlcow>
interesting that the dicussion around canonical html is coming back :)

[08:39:02.0000] <sayrer__>
"properly" is not an objective quality

[08:40:00.0000] <sayrer__>
and I'll note that conformance checker interoperability is not something the WG is chartered to take on

[08:40:01.0000] <sayrer__>
but it seems tangential to me, since conformance checkers are supposed to be the means, not the end

[08:40:02.0000] <Lachy>
no, I mean conformance checkers and validators. Lints offen flag stuff that isn't necessarily non-conforming, but which you might like to consider fixing anyway

[08:41:00.0000] <Lachy>
s/offen/often/

[08:41:01.0000] <sayrer__>
why do you need checker/validator rather than a lint tool?

[08:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
it depends on your individual needs and the capabilities of the lint tool in use

[08:43:00.0000] <Lachy>
e.g. you might have a lint which checks that an HTML document fits the criteria necessary for being a syntactically correct polyglot document, but which doesn't check any other conformance criteria.

[08:43:01.0000] <sayrer__>
I guess I don't understand whats motivating your position. do you feel validators force people to write good markup in some way?

[08:45:00.0000] <Lachy>
no, validators are very useful QA tools to help ensure the quality of the markup and catch mistakes. Conformance criteria help to ensure that different people are using a comment set of criteria, whcih makes it easier for developers to work together

[08:45:01.0000] <sayrer__>
common set of criteria?

[08:46:00.0000] <sayrer__>
lint tools are "are very useful QA tools to help ensure the quality of the markup and catch mistakes."

[08:46:01.0000] <sayrer__>
agree or disagree?

[08:46:02.0000] <sayrer__>
my feeling is that if you want validators to interoperate, you would make rules for validators

[08:46:03.0000] <Lachy>
partially agree. I've had experience with some lint tools that report useless information that I didn't need. But, they can be depending on your needs

[08:47:00.0000] <Lachy>
and also experience with lints that fail to report info that I do need

[08:48:00.0000] <Lachy>
sayrer__, the authoring conformance criteria in the spec do apply to validators. It says that explicitly in the conformance section

[08:49:00.0000] <sayrer__>
yes, I don't think that makes much sense.

[08:49:01.0000] <sayrer__>
validators aren't authors

[08:49:02.0000] <Lachy>
validators check markup on behalf of authors

[08:50:00.0000] <Lachy>
and if there weren't a common set of conformance criteria defined, then validators would vary significantly in what they report, and they wouldn't be particularly useful

[08:51:00.0000] <Lachy>
with a common set of criteria, developers can, in theory, use their favourite validation tools (perhaps based on the UI they like most) and be reasonably sure that they'll get equivalent results.

[08:52:00.0000] <sayrer__>
I am not sure how that became a goal, and it still seems tangential, since conforming HTML5 UAs will produce equivalent results no matter what

[08:52:01.0000] <Lachy>
I honestly do not understand your POV.

[08:52:02.0000] <sayrer__>
well, let's say one validator flags <font> and one doesn't

[08:53:00.0000] <sayrer__>
and the author happens to be using the validator that doesn't

[08:53:01.0000] <sayrer__>
so a <font> element has slipped through undetected

[08:53:02.0000] <sayrer__>
what is the interoperability consequence?

[08:54:00.0000] <Lachy>
that seems like a problem that only applies to your authoring-conformance-free spec

[08:54:01.0000] <sayrer__>
well, you are saying validators won't be useful without the requirements we have now

[08:54:02.0000] <sayrer__>
in a world without them, I expect some problems will occur if you are right

[08:55:00.0000] <sayrer__>
what is the problem that has occured here?

[08:56:00.0000] <Lachy>
from a browser POV, there isn't an interoperability issue. The issue is that different tools give authors different results. This reduces their ability to rely on tools to give useful results and could cause different people to argue about what's right and what's wrong, based on nothing more than the implementation decision of their favourite QA tools

[08:59:00.0000] <sayrer__>
so all validators must produce identical results?

[08:59:01.0000] <sayrer__>
and is it so bad if people argue about what's right and wrong?

[09:00:00.0000] <Lachy>
ideally, yes, as far as issuing errors is concerned. They can issue additional useful warnings based on the user's need

[09:00:01.0000] <Lachy>
or, actually, the user's desires

[09:00:02.0000] <sayrer__>
is that requirement in the spec?

[09:01:00.0000] <Lachy>
there's nothing in the spec to say that they can't issue additional warnings

[09:01:01.0000] <sayrer__>
is there a requirement that they must not issue additional errors?

[09:01:02.0000] <sayrer__>
otherwise, different tools could give different results

[09:01:03.0000] <Lachy>
no, tools are only allowed to issue errors defined in the spec

[09:02:00.0000] <sayrer__>
oh, I missed that. where is it?

[09:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
if it issues an error, or even treates something as a fatal error, where the spec doesn't say it can, then it has violated the actual criteria specified which doesn't say to issue an error

[09:07:00.0000] <sayrer__>
so then it couldn't issue an error for elements developed later

[09:07:01.0000] <sayrer__>
or elements in other namespaces

[09:07:02.0000] <sayrer__>
afaik, there are no fatal errors in HTML5

[09:08:00.0000] <sayrer__>
so far, I don't think there's anything in the spec that will enforce the level of interoperability you claim

[09:08:01.0000] <Lachy>
a spec that defines new elements would also update the relevant conformance criteria

[09:08:02.0000] <Lachy>
elements in other namespaces have their own criteria applying to them defined in their respective specs

[09:11:00.0000] <Lachy>
the parsing requirements allow implementations to treat errors as fatal instead of applying the corrective steps specified.

[09:12:00.0000] <Lachy>
"The error handling for parse errors is well-defined: user agents must either act as described below when encountering such problems, or must abort processing at the first error that they encounter for which they do not wish to apply the rules described below."

[09:13:00.0000] <sayrer__>
oh, that's very damaging to interoperability

[09:13:01.0000] <sayrer__>
but I thought that hedge existed for validators

[09:13:02.0000] <sayrer__>
it seems to have changed

[09:14:00.0000] <Lachy>
it depends on the needs of the specific implementation. Browsers, for example, couldn't really get away with aborting on errors in practice. But there are lots of other tools for which graceful error recovery is not essential

[09:15:00.0000] <Lachy>
A validator is one such use case for that

[09:15:01.0000] <Philip`>
Some (non-validator) tools really want streamability, and aborting on certain parse errors lets them do that

[09:15:02.0000] <sayrer__>
Lachy: not sure it is useful to claim they are conformant to the same spec

[09:15:03.0000] <sayrer__>
Philip`: yeah, a spider for instance

[09:15:04.0000] <Philip`>
(and they can streamably handle all conforming documents)

[09:16:00.0000] <sayrer__>
that last part is not true, since they can streamably all non-scripted conforming documents

[09:16:01.0000] <sayrer__>
streamably handle

[09:16:02.0000] <Lachy>
from memory, the adoption agency algorithm is one that affects streamability

[09:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
sayrer__: I'd expect most spiders would want to accept arbitrary input, and so they'd have to non-fatally handle invalid documents

[09:17:01.0000] <Lachy>
(hsivonen knows more about that, though)

[09:17:02.0000] <sayrer__>
Philip`: that's good point

[09:18:00.0000] <sayrer__>
I'll make a note about this

[09:18:01.0000] <Philip`>
sayrer__: I'm thinking of e.g. a tool that applies some kind of transformation to an HTML document, and doesn't want to buffer the whole document in memory

[09:18:02.0000] <Lachy>
sayrer__, tools that wish to incorporate an HTML5 parser into existing XML tool chains, and which require streamability, are likely to opt to abort on some errors

[09:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
e.g. a CMS that allows the author to write HTML, but which uses XML for everything else on the back end

[09:19:01.0000] <sayrer__>
they will probably opt out of more than just that

[09:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wrote a web service that converts HTML to XHTML streamingly, but (if he remembers correctly) it also aborted on cannot-serialise-to-XML errors

[10:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://hacks.mozilla.org/2009/07/video-more-than-just-a-tag/ - "<video id="myVideo" src="myFile.ogv"/>" - isn't that syntax going to break badly?

[11:11:00.0000] <Lachy>
we really should do more to promote better quality fallback, beyond the useless "You're browser doesn't support this"

[11:12:00.0000] <Lachy>
even a simple <a href="video.ogg">Download and watch</a> would be better

[11:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[07:47:00.0000] <eighty4>
uhm... nevermind that quote :)

[08:00:00.0000] <Lachy>

[08:06:00.0000] <eighty4>

[08:08:00.0000] <beowulf>

[08:08:01.0000] <eighty4>

[08:13:00.0000] <jgraham>
So I have a problem. I have a test harness which loads testcases into an iframe. It is not impossible that those testcases will cause infinite loops or other bad behaviour so it would be nice to be able to set a timeout and kill the script if the timeout is reached

[08:14:00.0000] <jgraham>
Howwever this doesn't seem to be easy; the event loop seems to prioritise running the existing script above anything else. 

[08:14:01.0000] <jgraham>
(run to completion I guess)

[08:14:02.0000] <Lachy>
eighty4, b is intended for use cases which are commenly represented typographically in bold text, but for which no specific semantic element exists

[08:15:00.0000] <Lachy>
eighty4, it would be unreasonable to have to create separate semantic elements to individually cover each of those cases, when it wouldn't gain any benefit over using the generic element

[08:15:01.0000] <jgraham>
Is there some way I force the source of the iframe to change before the testcase script has finished running?

[08:15:02.0000] <Lachy>
similarly for the i element

[08:15:03.0000] <eighty4>
beowulf: from what I understand it's not intended to represent bold text but rather like Lachy just wrote "text usually written in bold"

[08:15:04.0000] <jgraham>
(or close the window with the iframe in or delete the iframe or something, as long as it causes the script to die)

[08:16:00.0000] <Lachy>
eighty4, the names are retained for backwards compatibility reasons. It's best not to read too much into just the name of the element. It's the definition that matters mose

[08:17:00.0000] <eighty4>
Lachy: that explanation was good :) Not sure I'm agreeing with you but still.

[08:17:01.0000] <takkaria>
jgraham: I'm guessing that setTimeout() isn't being your friend

[17:06:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:15:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, what did you think of my suggestions for making that canvas example accessible? Were they reasonable given the contstraints, or is Joshue right about it being ridiculous?

[17:16:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
(...and it already has an accessible version anyway)

[17:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
though that one seems to be missing the descriptions

[17:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Animated image maps sound ridiculuous to me

[17:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
man, changing table taint is gonna be such a pain

[17:20:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you're going to all the trouble of maintaining a kind of scene graph DOM, you might as well just use SVG and then you won't have all the weirdness and restrictiveness of image map shapes

[17:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
that won't get you accessibility though

[17:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
(though for some reason, svg gets a free pass)

[17:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
s/ridiculuous/ridiculous/

[17:27:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, I know that specific page probably shouldn't use canvas, but there are lots of other interactive uses of canvas

[17:30:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, I don't see why animated image maps would be ridiculous. If you wanted to support keyboard navigation while still providing the same visual layout, how would you do it without throwing out the canvas entirely?

[17:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
you can't do it properly right now without using either svg or crazy image map stuff

[17:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't know how to make it possible though

[17:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
The image map keyboard navigation order will be completely unrelated to the spatial positions of the areas, so it's not a good way to provide keyboard navigation of the graphical display

[17:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
keyboard navigation is the one aspect of making canvas accessible that i might be able to figure out

[17:35:01.0000] <Lachy>
if you know the positions of the areas on the screen, it's conceivable that you could calculate a reasonable tab order and either set tabindex or do the complicated thing of reording the area elements in the DOM

[17:35:02.0000] <Philip`>
Anything that gives a linear keyboard navigation order will be operating over a separate view of the data from the non-linear graphical view, so it seems unhelpfully complex to try to mix both the views together instead of just providing two independent views

[17:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. by providing a hook for the canvas to say how it is willing to handle focus movement while the canvas is focused

[17:36:01.0000] <Philip`>
(where one view might be <canvas> and the other view might be a <table> or <ul> or something)

[17:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, providing 2 separate views doesn't solve the problem that Steve raised, which is that the original should be accessible, instead of having to maintain two completely different views

[17:38:00.0000] <Lachy>
although, in this case, as I mentioned in my email, the table view is probably useful for more than just accessibility reasons

[17:39:00.0000] <Lachy>
what if we took the concept of the image map and provided an API to declare a specific region of the canvas as being an active region which can respond to events?

[17:40:00.0000] <Lachy>
and which can recieve focus

[17:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
canvas.clearEventHandlers(); ctx.addEventHandlerOnClickInsideCurrentPath(function (evt) { ... })

[17:41:01.0000] <Lachy>
Then a backwards compatibility layer could possibly be provided by script libraries that generate equivalent image maps in the DOM

[17:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, I was thinking something like: region = context.createActiveRegion(...); region.addEventListener(...);

[17:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
that might be even better than doing it manually

[17:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
It'll be fun the first time someone creates a hundred active regions per frame, and forgets to delete them all before starting the next frame

[17:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah that's the main reason i prefer the manual approach

[17:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
anyway, hopefully the wai will advise us as to the best approach

[17:49:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, it might be better to just move the regions around, rather than delete and create new

[17:56:00.0000] <roc>

[17:57:00.0000] <roc>

[17:57:01.0000] <Lachy>

[17:58:00.0000] <roc>

[17:59:00.0000] <Lachy>

[18:00:00.0000] <roc>

[18:00:01.0000] <roc>

[18:01:00.0000] <Lachy>

[18:01:02.0000] <Lachy>

[18:01:03.0000] <Hixie>

[18:01:04.0000] <roc>

[18:02:00.0000] <Lachy>

[18:02:01.0000] <Lachy>

[18:03:00.0000] <roc>
you're talking about declaring "active regions"

[18:03:01.0000] <roc>
how is that not a parallel, accessible view?

[18:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
because it wouldn't just serve accessibility reasons. Imagine being able to declare an active region, and then just listen for clicks there, instead of having to calculate where on the canvas the click occurred

[18:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
It's still a parallel view which is accessible

[18:05:00.0000] <roc>
the cases where canvas wins most over SVG are where the information is dense

[18:05:01.0000] <roc>
like graphs, or an RTS where every pixel is custom rendered

[18:06:00.0000] <roc>
in those cases, you'll have zillions of active regions

[18:06:01.0000] <roc>
if you only have a few active regions, then you probably only have a few shapes, and you can use SVG

[18:06:02.0000] <Philip`>
http://philip.html5.org/demos/canvas/spritepick/example.html

[18:07:00.0000] <roc>

[18:07:02.0000] <roc>

[18:07:03.0000] <Philip`>

[18:07:04.0000] <roc>

[18:07:05.0000] <Lachy>

[18:07:06.0000] <Philip`>

[18:07:07.0000] <roc>

[18:08:00.0000] <roc>

[18:08:01.0000] <Lachy>

[18:08:02.0000] <roc>

[18:08:03.0000] <roc>

[18:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: as i said, the other solution is to provide a hook for script so that when the canvas is focused, if the user tabs or directionally navigates the focus, the canvas can say "ok keep the focus in the canvas, i can handle that one"

[18:09:01.0000] <Philip`>
roc: They might use it if it's the easiest way to support interactivity (i.e. clicking on regions), and a side-effect is that it can be exposed in a more accessible way

[18:09:02.0000] <Lachy>
there doesn't really seem to be a way for it to not be bolt on accessibility. But, as I said before, it could be leveraged for more than just accessibility purposes

[18:09:03.0000] <Philip`>
roc: It's kind of a pain to put onclick on the canvas and then have to manually work out which object was clicked on, so an API that makes that easier might get used by people who don't care about accessibility

[18:10:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, that sounds far more complicated than letting the browser itself help out

[18:10:01.0000] <roc>
Philip`: maybe, except for the problem I noted about having large numbers of regions

[18:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: maybe, i haven't compared the resulting code

[18:11:00.0000] <roc>
If the canvas contents are changing, then you have to maintain the set of regions and their geometry

[18:11:01.0000] <roc>
seems to me that's probably actually harder than writing your own picker code

[18:11:02.0000] <roc>
maintaining cached stuff persistently is almost always harder than just recomputing something whenever you need it

[18:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'm assuming you could just destroy and recreate all the regions every frame, at the same time as you're recreating all the rendered paths

[18:12:01.0000] <roc>
if you're doing that, then the actual code that walks the regions to do picking is relatively easy

[18:12:02.0000] <Philip`>
(Hooray for garbage collectors)

[18:13:00.0000] <roc>
maybe if you did beginRegion(...); draw draw draw; endRegion(...)

[18:17:00.0000] <Lachy>
interesting idea. So the region would include any pixel that was drawn on

[18:19:00.0000] <roc>
yeah

[18:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
What does "drawn on" mean?

[18:21:00.0000] <roc>
whatever we want it to mean

[18:21:01.0000] <roc>
that would be more convenient than writing your own custom picking code, so I can believe that people might actually use it

[18:21:02.0000] <roc>
and it might perform OK, since the browser can compute bounding boxes for you

[18:21:03.0000] <Philip`>
I can imagine it would relatively common to e.g. draw a shadowed box, and want to respond to the mouse being over the box and not its shadow

[18:21:04.0000] <roc>

[18:22:00.0000] <Philip`>

[19:01:00.0000] <Lachy>
so you would just keep it like it is on the whatwg copy with section specific status markers forever?

[19:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
sure

[19:06:00.0000] <Lachy>
we could effectively do that if we just treat the Recs as stable snapshots, and keep going with the same spec instead of starting fresh each time (which wouldn't be a good idea, anyway)

[19:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
that would require a change to the w3c process though

[19:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
you can't do LC->CR->PR->REC if you're just doing RECs as snapshots

[19:09:00.0000] <Lachy>
not really, since each time you begin work on the next version, you just fork the spec into, e.g. an HTML5 or HTML6 branch, which then continues along the Rec track while the trunk keeps going

[19:10:00.0000] <Lachy>
just like how software branches quite happily go through alphas->betas->release candidates->final

[19:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
oh hell, i'm not maintaining two branches of html5

[19:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's bad enough for code

[19:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not maintaining a 15 year branch

[19:14:00.0000] <Lachy>

[19:14:01.0000] <Lachy>
*HTML6

[19:17:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
but i think the problem is the process

[19:17:02.0000] <Lachy>
but with your model, it seems difficult for any specific section to ever be marked stable and stay that way for very long

[19:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
yup

[19:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's the point

[19:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
there is no stability here

[19:18:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's an ever-evolving platform

[19:18:04.0000] <Hixie>
the specs should reflect that

[19:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
but by publishing a stable snapshot, it allows implementers to clearly distinguish the stable sections from the new unstable sections

[19:20:00.0000] <Lachy>
so e.g. if video becomes widely implemented with its current feature set, and then you want to go add some new APIs after that, the new unstable stuff would be mixed in with the previously stable stuff

[19:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
i disagree with your use of the word "clearly"

[19:22:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:22:01.0000] <Hixie>

[19:25:00.0000] <Lachy>

[19:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
it doesn't ever work well

[19:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
it only vaguely works for software projects when they have very short lifetimes (weeks at most) and few checkins (just patches for crashes and stop-ship bugs)

[19:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
anything that has to either track another branch, or have bugs fixed in two or more branches, or merge back into another branch later, is a disaster

[19:35:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>

[19:43:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>

[00:40:00.0000] <hsivonen>
so, I think I should implement HTML5-compliant document.write timing behavior

[00:41:00.0000] <hsivonen>
basically prevent it from timeouts and such

[00:41:01.0000] <hsivonen>
is it correct that insertion point is

[00:41:02.0000] <hsivonen>
 1) Not defined when document.write runs synchronously and is not breaking on </script>

[00:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
 2) Defined when document.write breaks on </script>

[00:42:01.0000] <hsivonen>
 3) Defined when normal tokenization executes inline script on </script>

[00:43:00.0000] <hsivonen>
 4) Defined when an external non-defer script's load completes and it is run.

[00:43:01.0000] <hsivonen>
 5) (Not yet but per sicking's email will be) when the network stream has ended, there are only defer scripts left and a defer scripts is executed

[00:44:00.0000] <hsivonen>
 6) Not defined at any other time

[00:44:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Correct?

[07:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:25:01.0000] <Lachy>

[07:30:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:30:01.0000] <jgraham>

[07:32:00.0000] <jgraham>

[07:32:01.0000] <Philip`>

[07:35:01.0000] <jgraham>
(As Philip` or someone said the right test for video-on-the-web is to take multiple types of real world (i.e. lossy) input, reencode it to H.264/Theora/Dirac in a way that takes roughly the same time as youtube and produces roughly the same file sizes as youtube, and compare the resulting output)

[07:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me sees http://lwn.net/Articles/326830/ saying "If you are archiving video, building a unencumbered-bluray, or squeezing production grade 1080 HD video into 270mbit SD channels, Dirac is what you want. If you are webcasting with under a couple of megabits per second, Theora is what you want"

[07:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
though I'm not sure how much that's justified by data, or where the balancing point would be

[07:38:01.0000] <Lachy>
testing with lossy input makes it harder to compare the result, since so many of the artifacts in the output will be a direct result of the input, rather than the re-encoding process

[07:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
A hard-to-compare result sounds better than a result that's meaningless to anyone who wants to use the codecs in practice

[07:40:01.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Since the real world input is ally lossily encoded trying to remove that from the tests makes the tests less relevent

[07:40:02.0000] <Lachy>

[07:40:03.0000] <Lachy>
well, I disagree with both of you

[07:41:00.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: It depends what you are looking at. But if you are interested in video on the web you need to look at the type of source material that people actually use for video on the web

[07:42:00.0000] <jgraham>
Losslessly encoded sources are only one (rather rare) type of source material

[07:43:00.0000] <Lachy>
so, I'm only interested in the quality of the final encodes, since the results of encoding a lossless input to multiple encodings should show the same relative differences in output quality, as would a lossy input, but make it much clearer to judge the result

[07:44:00.0000] <jgraham>
That seems like a huge and, I think, provably false, assumption

[07:44:01.0000] <Philip`>
Are you assuming the quality of the output is directly proportional to the quality of the input?

[07:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
(e.g. if the lossly initial encoding is compresses in blocks then a lossy subsequent encoding that works with the same block size will look better than one that uses a totally different compression scheme, or has the blocks offset or something)

[07:45:01.0000] <jgraham>
s/l//

[07:46:00.0000] <jgraham>
(even if the other encoding scheme is "better" given ideal input)

[07:47:00.0000] <Lachy>
right, so if my input video used a lossy codec which unfairly favoured one of the output codecs due to block sizes or whatever, then the test would be biased.

[07:47:01.0000] <Philip`>
It seems like saying that if you have e.g. a lossless PDF document full of text and compress it as PNG and JPEG then PNG will do pretty well, and asserting that if you print out the PDF and take a photograph so you've got a lossy version then PNG will be relatively just as effective as before

[07:48:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, yeah, that['s true

[07:48:01.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Which is why the interesting test is to look at the actual inputs that people use. 

[07:50:00.0000] <Lachy>

[07:51:00.0000] <jgraham>

[07:52:00.0000] <Philip`>

[16:26:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I can understand people who want to write a strict syntax (subset), but is there really anything stricter about using <br/> than <br>? If anything, it leaves you open to <br/> vs <br />

[16:27:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Could've saved a lot of trouble if people had talked about strict HTML rather than saddling it on XHTML

[16:29:00.0000] <hober>
indeed

[16:55:00.0000] <tantek>
Dashiva - back in the day, many of us *did* talk about strict valid semantic HTML.

[16:56:00.0000] <tantek>
but HTML by then had already earned too much of a "presentational" reputation, even among web designers, especially among programmers.

[16:57:00.0000] <tantek>
XHTML 1.0 was an opportunity to present valid semantic HTML anew, and for the most part, it worked/works quite well.

[16:58:00.0000] <tantek>
eventually a lot of us started referring to good use of XHTML/HTML by the shorthand (X)HTML, which was sufficient to include those that really wanted to just use HTML4 really well.


2009-07-11
[17:06:00.0000] <tantek>
Dashiva - here is a short list of minor advantages to using XHTML rather than HTML: http://tantek.com/log/2003/01.html#L20030114t1345

[17:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
JavaScript variable scoping is great fun

[17:11:00.0000] <Philip`>

[17:11:01.0000] <Hixie>
fixed

[17:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
Ah, indeed

[17:12:01.0000] <Philip`>
It'd be nice if Opera didn't display the entire table before the canvas

[17:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
it shouldn't display the table at all

[17:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: that was a reasonable list of reasons at the time - I think nowadays most of them have been addressed by HTML5 or just general market changes

[17:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: I think it just totally fails to implement canvas child nodes correctly

[17:15:00.0000] <tantek>
HTML5 certainly goes a long way towards addressing  them, and certainly the web authoring community has made very good progress in better use of semantic (X)HTML.

[17:15:01.0000] <Philip`>
It parses <canvas> kind of like <script> or something

[17:16:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej, the reliable input to XML tools however is still a non-trivial advantage. For example, two very common microformats tools, X2V and Optimus, are both written in XSLT.

[17:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: odd

[17:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: file a bug

[17:16:03.0000] <tantek>
if parsing a page fails as XML, then the tools run tidy on the page to "clean it up" before retrying

[17:17:00.0000] <tantek>
since tidy is known to overly clean things up (e.g. strip elements with no contents, even if they have class and title attribute), it's still better to published well formed XML via XHTML.

[17:18:00.0000] <tantek>
also performance, as obviously trying once is faster than trying twice with a tidy clean step in the middle.

[17:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: I think html5lib and such are making that advantage less and less relevant

[17:20:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but sure, it might not be deployed in all the right places yet

[17:22:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej, I tend to agree, over time the magnitude of the advantage is likely to decrease due to tools like html5lib.

[17:22:01.0000] <tantek>
and yes, for now and the near future however, I can say it still very much makes a difference.

[17:23:00.0000] <tantek>
frankly, it's turned out to make more of a difference (e.g. the microformats XSLT tools people wrote) than I expected it to when I wrote that blog post 6 years ago.

[17:24:00.0000] <syp_>
Hixie: is it safe to assume element.classList will need to be case insensitive in quirks mode?

[17:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
syp_: no

[17:24:02.0000] <othermaciej>
well - it's only an advantage for microformats XSLT tools in the case where people are using such tools on content they control

[17:24:03.0000] <Hixie>
syp_: it is not safe to assume that

[17:25:00.0000] <syp_>
hmm, ok

[17:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
syp_: it might be true, though; what does the spec say?

[17:25:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if tools like that need to be able to extract from anything on the web, then it's outright a bug in those tools that they use libtidy when faced with HTML instead of XHTML

[17:25:03.0000] <syp_>
Hixie: it doesn't say anything for the moment, so I guess it means case sensitive.

[17:25:04.0000] <tantek>
sure, they may switch to using html5lib instead of tidy over time

[17:25:05.0000] <Hixie>
syp_: k. That seems best.

[17:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
syp_: you can't be in quirks mode in a conforming doc anyway.

[17:26:01.0000] <tantek>
but even with that substitution, the performance difference will still exist. one process step vs. two process steps with a html5lib conversion in the middle.

[17:26:02.0000] <Hixie>
crap meeting gotta go

[17:26:03.0000] <tantek>
To be clear, I've never really had much hope for XML on the web. Extensibility and everyone making up their own vocabularies means less likelihood of communication (especially across time), not more.

[17:26:04.0000] <tantek>
Thus XML methodologies were kind of doomed from the start as far as an update to the basic communication format of the Web. Never mind the ridiculous "must fail" approach.

[17:26:05.0000] <syp_>
Hixie: ok thanks

[17:27:00.0000] <tantek>
s/ridiculous/impractical

[17:28:00.0000] <syp_>
Hixie: I saw some comments in the mailing list about that, and other parts of the spec where classes are handled in a case insensitive way, that's why I was wondering.

[17:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: the downside risk to XHTML served as text/html is that there's no handy validator to tell you that your document is a correct chameleon document

[17:29:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej - the W3C validator does just fine.

[17:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so there's the risk of making something that will be misinterpreted depending on what tool is reading it

[17:29:02.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: does it have a special "appendix C" mode?

[17:29:03.0000] <tantek>
it validates it as XHTML, even if served as text/html

[17:29:04.0000] <othermaciej>
validating as XHTML is not validating whether it means the same thing interpreted as HTML and XML

[17:30:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej - last I checked it hard *warnings* for Appendix C violations on XHTML 1.0 documents served as text/html.

[17:30:01.0000] <tantek>
s/hard/had

[17:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
that's probably good enough

[17:30:03.0000] <tantek>
that's kind of what I figured too.

[17:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(only remaining risks would be to obscure script issues, but that's only an issue if serving to real browsers as both mime types, not so much to pure data processing tools)

[17:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I hope validator.nu gets a chameleon checking mode even though I bet hsivonen hates the idea of chameleon documents

[17:31:02.0000] <tantek>
agreed. and it's impractical to serve anything but text/html to browsers.

[17:32:00.0000] <tantek>
or rather, it's impractical to depend on "must fail" MIME types, e.g. serve application/xml(+*) to browsers.

[17:33:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej I for one like chameleon documents, and even code too.

[17:33:01.0000] <tantek>
see for example: http://tantek.pbworks.com/CassisProject

[17:34:00.0000] <tantek>
such chameleon documents/code typically have greater utility than either of the two single formats/languages on their own.

[17:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: that's wild

[00:23:00.0000] <gmaxwell>
I see that Till Halbach's dirac/theora/h264 comparison was mentioned. Beyond the point about it being old, three independent parties have been unable to reproduce his results using the same software versions. While H.264 and dirac numbers have good agreement, his theora numbers are ~15dB lower than anyone else gets (on Akiyo, for example).  In spite of this he has been unwilling to check his measurements or post any notes on this point.   T

[00:23:01.0000] <gmaxwell>
his is further supported by his example image:  http://etill.net/projects/dirac_theora_evaluation/include/visual_comparison.png  The sequence being  original, dirac at 67kbit/sec, theora at 18kbit/sec, h264 at 17kbit/sec, while the charts theora is show as something like 10dB worse than the dirac which is clearly not the case from the example.  ::shrugs:: Take that for what you will.

[00:26:00.0000] <gmaxwell>
As far as the prior comments about what I sent to youtube—  The provided upload limits and supported formats constrained my choices.  The MJPEG was the best I they appeared to accept, and anything larger would have interacted poorly with the upload size cap.   The Theora and Youtube started from the same input. ::shrugs::   But if you're worried about points like this you've missed the point of the comparison, it was intended to be an ord

[00:26:01.0000] <gmaxwell>
er of magnitude kind of thing.   A detailed comparison would require many kinds of input, etc. 

[00:27:00.0000] <gmaxwell>
And would have been an enormous amount of work, which I can't justify spending my time on because the people I work with would never consider using H.264 in any case due to the licensing.

[00:27:01.0000] <gmaxwell>
Cheers.

[22:24:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:25:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:25:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:27:00.0000] <jacobolus>

[22:27:01.0000] <jacobolus>
i.e. close the comment when they see --!>

[22:28:00.0000] <jacobolus>

[22:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:29:01.0000] <jacobolus>

[22:29:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[22:35:00.0000] <jacobolus>

[22:35:01.0000] <jacobolus>
maybe I should file an opera bug

[22:37:00.0000] <jacobolus>
(though they probably know this, w/ annevk &c. paying attention)

[22:52:00.0000] <jacobolus>
oh wow, the opera behavior is odd indeed

[22:52:01.0000] <jacobolus>
if it only finds --!>, then it treats it as a comment ending

[22:52:02.0000] <jacobolus>
but if there's --> anywhere later, it'll use that as the end of the comment

[22:53:00.0000] <jacobolus>
swallowing anything in between

[22:53:01.0000] <jacobolus>
so adding a comment way down the page completely changes rendering

[22:53:02.0000] <jacobolus>
I guess I will file that bug

[23:01:00.0000] <jacobolus>
for any opera devs here, bug 258698

[23:07:00.0000] <jacobolus>
example html that causes this behavior in latest Opera 10 preview: http://pastie.textmate.org/542877

[23:30:00.0000] <jacobolus>
(hsivonen/Hixie: you might be interested in that... dunno)

[01:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
jacobolus: If I remember correctly, if it reaches EOF with an unclosed comment then it re-parses and closes the comment on the first >, or something like that

[01:09:00.0000] <jacobolus>
huh. well I can put in multiple 'fake' comments and they work fine

[01:09:01.0000] <jacobolus>
but as soon as I add a real one, even way down the page, they all break

[01:09:02.0000] <jacobolus>
you could be right that that's the behavior. I'll test a bit

[01:10:00.0000] <jacobolus>

[01:10:01.0000] <jacobolus>
so they probably already had this as a bug

[01:11:00.0000] <jacobolus>
sadly, the database is closed...

[01:13:00.0000] <jacobolus>

[01:13:01.0000] <jacobolus>

[11:39:00.0000] <Simetrical>
So <!doctype html> actually triggers different behavior from old doctypes, it seems?

[11:39:01.0000] <Simetrical>
That's . . . bad?

[11:39:02.0000] <Philip`>
Simetrical: Depends which old doctypes you mean

[11:39:03.0000] <Simetrical>
Well, I'm working on switching Wikipedia from XHTML 1.0 Transitional to HTML 5.

[11:40:00.0000] <Simetrical>
When I switch the doctype, rendering breaks.

[11:40:01.0000] <Simetrical>
That will make things *much* more complicated.

[11:40:02.0000] <Simetrical>
I had thought that the doctype was chosen specifically so it would trigger standards mode in all browsers, but it seems that's not quite the case.

[11:40:03.0000] <Simetrical>
Hmm.

[11:40:04.0000] <Philip`>

[11:40:06.0000] <Philip`>
(and <!doctype html> is "Standards")

[11:41:00.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:41:01.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:41:02.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:41:03.0000] <Philip`>

[11:41:04.0000] <Philip`>

[11:41:05.0000] <Simetrical>
Oh, I see.

[11:42:00.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:42:01.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, http://hsivonen.iki.fi/doctype/ already talks about Almost Standards

[11:42:02.0000] <Simetrical>
Current MediaWiki doctype: <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">

[11:42:03.0000] <Philip`>
"which implements the vertical sizing of table cells traditionally and not rigorously according to the CSS2 specification"

[11:43:00.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:43:01.0000] <Simetrical>
Specifically including . . . all recent browsers.

[11:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
That sounds correct

[11:44:00.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:44:01.0000] <Simetrical>

[11:44:02.0000] <Philip`>

[12:01:00.0000] <Philip`>

2009-07-13
[20:24:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://svwebbuilder.wordpress.com/2008/10/16/html-5-the-future-is-now/

[20:24:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
"The WebSocket JavaScript API provides the equivalent of a desktop style TCP connection, limited to text-based payloads for now, because JavaScript does not yet have a byte or ByteArray type."

[20:24:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I thought Javascript does actually have a byte type

[20:26:00.0000] <doublec>
nope

[20:26:01.0000] <doublec>
arrays of numbers is what you need to do for byte arrays

[20:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[20:27:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
What's the rationale for it not having a byte type?

[20:27:02.0000] <othermaciej>
array of numbers and improper string are the two ways of doing it

[20:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there is no rationale, just hasn't been done yet

[20:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(although I don't think there is really a good strawman spec before the ECMAScript committee yet for a type to hold binary data)

[20:28:02.0000] <othermaciej>
array of numbers is much much much less efficient than a proper ByteArray could be

[20:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I guess it'll be especially limiting in the case of WebSocket-based apps

[20:29:01.0000] <doublec>
yes

[20:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"The WebSocket wire protocol itself can represent either binary or text payloads, so languages other than JavaScript that do have a binary representation can choose to send binary data to a WebSocket server in the raw, rather than having to encode the binary data as text."

[20:30:01.0000] <doublec>
I wrote some code to read/process Ogg files from JavaScript and used the improper string approach

[20:30:02.0000] <doublec>
but it's not cross platform afaik since there's no way to say 'give me binary data' from xmlhttprequest

[20:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, seems like we are going to have a much more compelling need for it, once websocket gets supported in browsers

[20:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there is already a pretty compelling need for it

[20:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
binary XHR is a pretty big use case

[20:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
IMO

[20:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
there's no clean way to either upload or retrieve binary data via XHR

[20:41:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: so nobody's submitted a spec proposal to the ECMAScript TC yet?

[20:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: there have been some vague proposals

[20:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe I will try to propose something more concrete

[20:43:02.0000] <othermaciej>
this is the biggest hole in standards development right now IMO

[20:47:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: concrete proposal would be great to have

[20:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I want to be the first to write a VOIP server in Javascript :)

[20:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there's bigger pieces missing there than binary data

[20:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
like the ability to play and record raw audio data

[21:18:00.0000] <heycam>
Web IDL has arrays now though, so you can have a type octet[]

[21:19:00.0000] <heycam>
it's not quite the same as the original ES3 ByteArray

[21:19:01.0000] <heycam>
no constructor

[21:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that solves the Web IDL side, but not how you represent it in ECMAScript

[21:24:00.0000] <heycam>
there's http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebIDL/#es-array

[21:24:01.0000] <heycam>
or do you mean something else

[21:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I see, I didn't know about that

[21:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I will amend my comment to: I don't think that's a very good way to represent binary data in ECMAScript

[21:30:00.0000] <slightlyoff>
othermaciej: generally as an objection to some sort of binary array? or the particulars of this outline which doesn't require changes to JS to do it?

[21:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
slightlyoff: I think it's a poor design for a type to deal with binary data

[21:30:02.0000] <slightlyoff>
ah, OK, +1 to that = )

[21:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think a binary data type should be immutable, like JS strings

[21:31:01.0000] <slightlyoff>
hrm

[21:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
or maybe have an explicit copy to get a mutable variant

[21:31:03.0000] <slightlyoff>
I'd prefer that we have a Packed array type

[21:31:04.0000] <slightlyoff>
and maybe we have fixed and non-fixed variants

[21:32:00.0000] <slightlyoff>
with ByteArray being a subclass of that

[21:32:01.0000] <slightlyoff>
(or uses it to mix in)

[21:33:00.0000] <slightlyoff>
making it immutable seems maybe less important than not needing to accomidate the sparseness

[21:33:01.0000] <heycam>
othermaciej, is it just the mutability that you think is a poor choice?

[21:33:02.0000] <othermaciej>
because a key use case is to hold underlying raw data buffers

[21:34:00.0000] <slightlyoff>
so there are some cases where we'd like to enforce the length that was handed up?

[21:34:01.0000] <heycam>
there's a concept of read only arrays: http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebIDL/#dfn-read-only-array

[21:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
heycam: well, I'm concerned in general about Web IDL minting new types to that extent

[21:34:03.0000] <heycam>
and fixed length ones too: http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/WebIDL/#dfn-fixed-length

[21:34:04.0000] <slightlyoff>
ugg

[21:35:00.0000] <slightlyoff>
I mean, not bad, but they seem poorly integrated w/ JS as a language

[21:35:01.0000] <slightlyoff>
(which prolly means JS needs to catch up)

[21:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it has a whole lot of concepts that aren't really used by the existing IDL-using specs, and defining them in this way will make things awkward when/if JS can better represent some of these concepts in the language itself

[21:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I have to go soon

[21:35:04.0000] <othermaciej>
but as a parting note

[21:36:00.0000] <heycam>
that's a good point, sure

[21:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
perhaps programming in Cocoa has spoiled me, but my experience with NSData convinces me that binary data should be its own kind of basic data type, like strings, rather than treating it like a kind of array

[21:37:00.0000] <heycam>
i've never programmed in cocoa so i don't know what goodness NSData gives you

[21:37:01.0000] <heycam>
but anyway, please do comment on the list when you get a chance

[21:37:02.0000] <slightlyoff>
fair enough, but I'd like that discussion to happen vis-a-vie JS rather than WebIDL, which sounds like what you're suggesting too

[21:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
it's not really specific goodness, just the clarity

[21:37:04.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, I think this is an issue for the ECMAScript group

[21:38:00.0000] <heycam>
they don't seem interested in pushing ByteArray right at the moment

[21:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Web IDL should maybe trim back some of the more novel inventions

[21:38:02.0000] <heycam>
and i think we (the platform) need something like that soon

[21:38:03.0000] <slightlyoff>
they is us....I say we push it = )

[21:38:04.0000] <heycam>
