[03:09:01.0000] <boblet>
A question regarding the header element; the content model is flow but no header or footer element descendants. That means it could contain a section, but the contained section couldn’t contain a header, right?

[03:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
right

[03:09:03.0000] <boblet>
So that means a complex page header (eg containing sections with headers) will need to be a section huh

[03:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
the nested section could contain <h1>s and <hgroup>s and such like

[03:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
but it couldn't contain its own <header>

[03:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
if you have an example of when that might make sense, though, let us know

[03:10:03.0000] <Hixie>
the idea of restricting it was we couldn't find any case where it made sense, and we found lots of cases where it didn't and we wanted to discourage people misusing it for those cases

[03:11:00.0000] <boblet>
hmm, ok. It does make sense, I just wanted to check I was understanding it

[16:07:00.0000] <Lachy>
wow, I just read through that RDFa in HTML draft, and there are so many issues with it

[16:09:00.0000] <Lachy>
from the last paragraph: "Since CURIE prefix mappings have been specified using xmlns:, and since HTML attribute names are case-insensitive, CURIE prefix names declared using the xmlns:attribute-name pattern xmlns:<PREFIX>="<URI>" should be specified using only lower-case characters. For example, the text "xmlns:" and the text in "<PREFIX>" should be lower-case only. This is to ensure that prefix mappings are interpreted in the same way between HTML (case

[16:09:01.0000] <Lachy>
-insensitive attribute names) and XHTML (case-sensitive attribute names) document types."

[16:11:00.0000] <Lachy>
that seems to indicate that there are some unspecified problems when using uppercase, but says nothing about how to handle it. Though, presumably, it doesn't really matter, since the parser lowercases them anyway, and it's only a problem if you are making a polyglot document

[16:12:00.0000] <Lachy>
it's not really clear if that's what it means though

[16:14:00.0000] <Lachy>
"If an author is unsure of the final encapsulating DOCTYPE for their markup..." -- what the?

[15:49:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, so we ran into an minor issue implementing .files on drag-n-drop dataTransfer

[15:49:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=503598#c18

[15:49:02.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, basically, we don't want to expose the files during drags

[15:49:03.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, but i suspect we want to expose the fact that there are files in there

[15:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah you should only expose them ondrop

[15:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
/me looks at the bug

[15:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
(same applies to all data, not just files)

[15:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
if you get arun to finish his draft, i'll spec this in the html5 spec immediately

[15:52:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, i'm talking with Arun fairly often about the draft, i think a new one is on the way

[15:52:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, i don't think it'll change substantially though from previous one. Possibly introducing the local-uri thing

[15:53:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, though the lifetime still seems like a big problem to me

[15:54:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, and I think we might drop the FileDialog for now. Because ya'll are wossies ;)

[15:56:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, so in general for drag-n-drop, pages won't know at all even what type of data is in the datatransfer until the drop event?

[15:57:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, seems useful for the page to know if it will be able to handle the datatype before accepting the drop

[15:57:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, this would be orthogonal to the .files issue

[16:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: what's the problem with the lifetime? and i hope he'll split File into File and some base interface, too

[16:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: the problem with not knowing the types is an open issue with the dnd model iirc

[16:25:00.0000] <Dashiva>
The @parsing thing doesn't seem like a good fit for markup

[16:25:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, the problem with the life time is that I suspect Document lifetime is slightly too short

[16:25:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Browser error reporting, symlinks, mod_rewrite with type override...

[16:25:03.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: for the types, i expect we'll expose .types in all events in the future

[16:25:04.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, for example sticking the uri into a sessionStorage in a wizard-type page

[16:25:05.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, sounds good re .types

[16:26:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, we'd just need to define a type for files

[16:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: well we can always increase the lifetime later if we think we need to... but i think it'd be better to define a way to track the actual File or FileData objects rather than passing the URI around

[16:27:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, yeah, that's an alternative

[16:27:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, i'd still like for Storage to be able to hold File/FileData objects

[16:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the temporary URI design is probably not workable

[16:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I need to catch up on the discussion though

[16:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i don't see another solution for reusing file data unless we basically add a parallel set of features across the entire platform to support File objects everywhere, and that seems painful

[16:28:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the problem is, you have to make sure that temporary URIs for files are unguessable, and also that they are never reused

[16:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
why and why?

[16:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
they have to be unguessable or you have a security hole

[16:29:02.0000] <othermaciej>
an attacker in a different window could read the URI

[16:29:03.0000] <Hixie>
no, they are origin-blocked

[16:29:04.0000] <othermaciej>
assuming you want the URIs to be passable via postMessage for instance

[16:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
you'd pass the File object

[16:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
not the URI

[16:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
in that case, they are inferior to the ability to pass a File since you can't transfer the capability

[16:30:03.0000] <Hixie>
correct

[16:30:04.0000] <Hixie>
they're not meant for passing around

[16:30:05.0000] <Hixie>
they're meant for plugging a File object into an <img> or <video> or some such

[16:30:06.0000] <othermaciej>
so it seems like adding srcFile attributes to the few HTML element interfaces that need them would be simpler

[16:30:07.0000] <Hixie>
or <iframe>, or CSS, or any number of things

[16:30:08.0000] <Hixie>
that seems unworkable to me

[16:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
we'd have to go through the entire platform duplicating everything, defining how one overrides the other, etc

[16:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
it'd be an epic disaster in terms of getting interop

[16:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(I don't think <iframe> or CSS really need them, but maybe I'm wrong)

[16:31:03.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, why make them origin blocked rather than unguessable?

[16:31:04.0000] <othermaciej>
the use case is for a preview

[16:32:00.0000] <sicking>
I think CSS and <iframe> is useful for things like building a HTML editor

[16:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think giving <img>, <audio> and <video> a way to take their source from a file instead of a URI would mostly satisfy the use case

[16:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
building an HTML editor would admittedly need support everywhere you can embed something

[16:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if you wanted your HTML editor to work without having to upload the resources first

[16:33:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but I thought the main stated use case was for previews before uploading

[16:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(any text resource you can already preview by reading the file yourself)

[16:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
temporary URIs are certainly more general, but more complicated both to use and to implement for the simple preview use case

[16:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: because they can leak easily (e.g. referer headers)

[16:35:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, hmm... good point

[16:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think that temporary URIs are actually any more complicated on the long term

[16:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
they would be a much more localised implementation

[16:35:03.0000] <Hixie>
rather than spreading support all over the place, redefining processing models, etc

[16:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
a more localized implementation of something way more complicated, and with tricky security implications

[16:36:01.0000] <sicking>
if we make the uri origin blocked then I'm not sure there are any security issues I can think of off the top of my head

[16:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i'm not convinced it's that complicated. Why would it be that complicated?

[16:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
tracking the temp URIs and implementing lifetime and origin blocking is the piece of code that would be both complicated and security-sensitive

[16:37:02.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, btw, doesn't data: uri suffer the same problem of leaking through referrer then?

[16:37:03.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: data: URIs aren't particularly secure

[16:38:00.0000] <sicking>
origin blocking doesn't seem that hard to implement security, granted it might be different in non-gecko browsers

[16:38:01.0000] <sicking>
securely

[16:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: it's just a table of ID,origin,file,document; when a document closes, you remove all the corresponding rows; whena url is dereferenced, it returns its origin and data

[16:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: unless your URI handling is especially weird, this seems relatively straightforward

[16:39:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: if lifetime is document but scope is origin, you have to be careful never to reuse an ID

[16:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that's one example of a potential subtle bug

[16:40:01.0000] <otherarun>
So the requirement is for both unguessability and origin-restriction.

[16:40:02.0000] <otherarun>
(the first, unguessability, may be easy -- UUID or something)

[16:40:03.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: not reusing an ID is trivial, just increase a number.

[16:40:04.0000] <othermaciej>
unguessability doesn't matter if they are origin restricted

[16:40:05.0000] <sicking>
at least not as important

[16:41:00.0000] <sicking>
though <img> is cross origin

[16:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i don't really understand the not reusing an ID thing, though

[16:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: it's easier to avoid repeating if the URI doesn't have to be unguessable

[16:41:03.0000] <sicking>
/me didn't follow the reuse ID thing either

[16:41:04.0000] <Hixie>
so long as you don't create a new URI that's equal to a still-active URI, why does it matter if the ID is reused?

[16:41:05.0000] <othermaciej>
if you reuse an ID then it could lead to another page from the same origin that has the wrong URI reference to load the wrong file, instead of getting an error

[16:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
that seems like a not especially worrisome case

[16:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
i mean, that page could just randomly come up with a string that happens to be one that happens to be registered to its own origin too

[16:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
even if the ID wasn't reused

[16:42:03.0000] <othermaciej>
note that File references wouldn't have this problem at all, since the engine can know the lifetime of a File object but it can't know the object of a URI string

[16:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: yes, that's another flaw with the magical URI scheme

[16:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it just has much more potential for bugginess to use a magic string instead of a capability-carrying object reference

[16:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think that considering this a flaw is like considering pointers to be flawed because if you come up with a random number that happens to point into your address space, you'll dereference something instead of getting an access violation

[16:43:03.0000] <othermaciej>
to identify a temporary and origin-restricted resource

[16:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
pointers are flawed! that's why we don't have them in ECMAScript

[16:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
*shrug* i'm not convinced this is a problem

[16:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
i mean i'm happy to make the URIs be unlikely to be reused and unlikely to clash

[16:44:03.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. by using UUIDs

[16:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
(clash with random values, i mean)

[16:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
but i don't think it's a problem

[16:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's just a sloppy design, in my opinion

[16:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
but in any case, it's trivial to create a sequence of non-duplicate IDs that are statistically not going to clash with random numbers

[16:46:02.0000] <othermaciej>
not saying we can't make it work, but it will be much more bug-prone than the alternative

[16:46:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's far less sloppy than adding a parallel set of APIs everywhere :-)

[16:46:04.0000] <Hixie>
i strongly disagree with that

[16:46:05.0000] <Hixie>
having to add two entry points to every processing model is orders of magnitude more likely to be buggy

[16:46:06.0000] <Hixie>
and in weird ways that are hard to work aorund

[16:47:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
Speaking of dnd... The current draft doesn't specify when pageX, clientX, screenX positions are available on the DragEvent. Gecko currently sets these to zero on the source node. It should be available on all IMHO. Is there any known security issues to this?

[16:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I doubt it. Just say srcFile always takes precedence over src, or the most recently set takes precedence, or whatever. Done.

[16:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: hah

[16:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: if only it were that easy

[16:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>
It would be like an hour or two of implementation work to do HTMLImageElement.srcFile and I would be confident it is right

[16:48:03.0000] <othermaciej>
a temporary URI vending scheme, I would expect to be finding bugs months later

[16:48:04.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: and you'd get the origin checking right for when that <img> is used with createPattern() ?

[16:49:00.0000] <sicking>
the downside is that we can't make it work as widely as URIs work. For example for CSS backgrounds. But i'm not sure that that is that important

[16:49:01.0000] <othermaciej>
sicking: yeah, that's really the main downside

[16:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: an <img> loaded from a File shouldn't have cross-origin taint, since if you have the file reference you can get the bits of the image

[16:50:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or at least, cross-origin taint for createPattern() would serve no useful purpose

[16:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i'm just saying that there are FAR more complications here than first meets the eye

[16:50:03.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. we'd have to change the conformance rules to make sure <img> without src="" would be valid

[16:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
the <video> resource selection algorithm would become even more complex

[16:51:01.0000] <roc>
I'd prefer the URI approach from an implementation point of view. If we do the .file approach we'll have to wrap the file in a URI-like-stream internally anyway

[16:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
anyone relying on selectors like  img[src]  would have to now know they couldn't always rely on it

[16:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm willing to believe there may be complications, I just can't think of any (at least, none that would make it tricky for implementations)

[16:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
there are so many small things that would have to be defined if we added a parallel API everywhere

[16:52:02.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: I think the challenges with the URI approach are not so much about using it internally, but in using that URI string as a handle to the resource

[16:52:03.0000] <Hixie>
you also couldn't use .innerHTML suddenly, you'd have to create the markup and then poke the file in afterwards

[16:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess I'm not really sure it's needed everywhere

[16:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think it's needed everywhere, e.g. i can't think of any time i'd want to put it in <blockquote cite="">

[16:54:01.0000] <roc>
Maintaining a file dictionary doesn't seem that hard, except for lifetime management. How does that work?

[16:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the only use case I've heard mentioned for that is a full-featured HTML editor that either works offline or is unwilling to upload resources before using them in editing

[16:54:03.0000] <roc>
Hixie: I can!

[16:54:04.0000] <Hixie>
roc: my proposal is to make the URIs stop resolving once their Document has been closed

[16:55:00.0000] <sicking>
/me has to take off

[16:55:01.0000] <roc>
ok

[16:55:02.0000] <sicking>
so far I don't feel strongly either way

[16:55:03.0000] <roc>
sounds good to me

[16:58:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
othermaciej: It could really be all kinds of offline app scenarios such as spreadsheets or whatever.

[16:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
sebmarkbage: I don't think spreadsheets need the ability to reference a temporary file from CSS to work offline

[16:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
being able to read the file text, plus maybe ability to display loaded images, should be enough


2009-07-15

[10:15:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:15:01.0000] <ezyang>

[10:15:02.0000] <ezyang>
erm, s/html5lib/HTML 5/ 

[10:15:03.0000] <Philip`>

[10:15:04.0000] <Philip`>

[10:16:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:17:00.0000] <ezyang>

[10:19:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:20:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:20:01.0000] <ezyang>

[10:21:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:21:03.0000] <jgraham>

[10:22:00.0000] <ezyang>

[10:22:01.0000] <Philip`>

[10:23:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:24:00.0000] <ezyang>

[10:24:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
(I presume the main point of a non-conforming-to-conforming converter is to let you get ticks, because in terms of e.g. preserving the author's intent it's going to be worse than HTML5's processing requirements for non-conforming content)

[10:25:01.0000] <ezyang>
I mean, ideally the form processor would be smart enough to recognize these unresolvable cases and ask the user what they actually meant. 

[10:26:00.0000] <ezyang>

[10:26:01.0000] <jgraham>
?!?

[10:26:02.0000] <ezyang>

[10:26:03.0000] <ezyang>

[10:26:04.0000] <ezyang>
When I say intent, I mean, the way browsers will deal with it. 

[10:27:00.0000] <ezyang>
i.e. it gives desirable security properties. 

[10:27:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:27:02.0000] <jgraham>

[10:27:03.0000] <jgraham>

[10:27:04.0000] <gsnedders>
jgraham: XSS

[10:27:05.0000] <Philip`>
ezyang: If the goal is to fix markup that will have browser behaviour differences, then that seems very different to translating all non-conforming markup

[10:28:00.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: Conforming code can have XSS holes

[10:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. you wouldn't have to worry about img with no alt even if it was non-conforming

[10:28:02.0000] <gsnedders>
jgraham: <a href=`javascript:alert("so sue me")`>asd</a> will run the JS in IE but is non-conforming

[10:28:03.0000] <ezyang>
Right, so there are multiple issues here. 

[10:28:04.0000] <gsnedders>
Actually, I don't think that is non-conforming.

[10:28:05.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: Right so you should strip that in a sanitizer, conforming or not

[10:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
and you would have to worry about conforming code like <!--[if IE 6]><script>alert("oh no")</script><![endif]-->

[10:29:01.0000] <ezyang>
From the XSS standpoint, syntactic conformance is a huge plus. Not as much for tags, although by whitelisting to conformant tags and then further removing problem tags, you further restrict things. 

[10:29:02.0000] <gsnedders>
It probably should be non-conforming, though, for the very reason that IE will execute that

[10:29:03.0000] <ezyang>
Philip`: I explicitly disallow comments because of the fact that they commonly carry out of band information that is exploitable 

[10:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
ezyang: So you're making a sanitiser, rather than a tool to convert non-conforming markup to conforming markup?

[10:30:01.0000] <jgraham>

[10:30:02.0000] <ezyang>

[10:30:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:30:04.0000] <Philip`>

[10:30:05.0000] <jgraham>

[10:30:06.0000] <gsnedders>
http://htmlpurifier.org/demo.php

[10:31:00.0000] <ezyang>

[10:31:01.0000] <ezyang>
It is then that alt attributes are relevant. 

[10:31:02.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:31:03.0000] <jgraham>

[10:31:04.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:32:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:32:01.0000] <jgraham>

[10:32:02.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:32:03.0000] <Philip`>

[10:33:00.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: The problem with trying to make code valid is you can quite easily make it a lot worse from a conformance and accessibility point of view

[10:33:01.0000] <ezyang>
I think alt is the big offender. 

[10:36:00.0000] <ezyang>
So, to reiterate, conformance has various benefits: 1. you get validator ticks, 2. syntactic conformance makes XSS harder, 3. conforming HTML has more regular browser interpretation, letting us canonicalize the interpretation 

[10:36:01.0000] <ezyang>
You roll over accessibility in the img alt case, but this can be fixed by smarter form processing, and is fairly isolated. 

[10:39:00.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: 1 is not a benefit.

[10:39:01.0000] <jgraham>
1 is not a benefit on its own. 2 seems extremely dubious to me. 3 is probably true but since you are basically just putting things through a magic black box you still won't get the results you expect in many cases

[10:39:02.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: 2 doesn't need validity

[10:40:00.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: 3 can't really be done programmatically.

[10:40:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(I say 2 doesn't need validity as it can be done just by doing stuff token-by-token)

[10:40:02.0000] <gsnedders>
(You can get a lot of the benefits of 2 just by parsing then serializing, and doing nothing more)

[10:41:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:42:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[10:49:00.0000] <ezyang>
gsnedders: There is one main point that requires some sort of tree building algorithm, which is preventing user HTML elements from leaking to the parent tree. 

[10:50:00.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: Sure, just parse and serialize to get there.

[10:50:01.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: Nothing more than that is needed for that,

[10:50:02.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: Also, both myself and jgraham have doubts over two, as most of the issues will be fixed by parsing and serializing the tree, provided you quote attribute values and special case one or two things like < in tag name

[10:50:03.0000] <ezyang>
Whitelist philosophy means that I should very thoroughly inspect attributes and recursively parse data formats (i.e. CSS to URI) 

[10:51:00.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: Sure, but that doesn't have anything to do with building a balanced tree

[10:51:01.0000] <ezyang>
It also means that I should know exactly what tags that I'm going to allow. 

[10:51:02.0000] <jgraham>

[10:51:03.0000] <ezyang>
Ok, so the core issues 

[10:52:00.0000] <ezyang>
building a conforming tree, and generating required attributes 

[10:52:01.0000] <ezyang>
Which y'all would like to convince me to not do. 

[10:53:00.0000] <ezyang>
Everything else that HTML Purifier is useful, no? 

[10:53:01.0000] <ezyang>
*is doing 

[10:53:02.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: You cannot create a conforming tree programmatically. You can, however, produce a valid tree.

[10:54:00.0000] <ezyang>
oh yes, that's what I meant 

[10:54:01.0000] <jgraham>
ezyang: I expect so althogh I don't know what all the other things it is doing are

[10:54:02.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: Everything else meaning what?

[10:54:03.0000] <ezyang>
With regards to fulfilling HTML 5 conformance requirements 

[10:55:00.0000] <ezyang>
We want to fulfill syntactic conformance, which you get from tokenizing the stream 

[10:55:01.0000] <ezyang>
We want to build a tree, which has its own conformance things associated with it (i.e. <b><i>f</b></i>), which you get from tree-building 

[10:55:02.0000] <jgraham>
The point about trying to create valid markup is that the main benefit seems to be a happy feeling conformance tick but there are substantial costs in terms of complexity, possibilites of harming end users, possibility of automagically misinterpreting the markup

[10:56:00.0000] <ezyang>
We want to recursively validate attributes, which increases conformance 

[10:56:01.0000] <gsnedders>
What does HTML Purifier aim to do? Does it aim to produce secure markup, does it aim to produce valid markup?

[10:56:02.0000] <ezyang>
It aims to do both. 

[10:56:03.0000] <ezyang>
You could remove maybe 15% if you got rid of the valid markup requirement, specifically valid trees and attribute generation. 

[10:57:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Fundamentally the latter is not a useful goal.

[10:57:01.0000] <ezyang>
The primary complexity comes from whitelisting and attribute validation 

[10:57:02.0000] <ezyang>
Possibly. 

[10:57:03.0000] <gsnedders>
You will get a lot of it from just parsing and serializing the tree, certainly

[10:57:04.0000] <gsnedders>
But that is a side-effect, more than anything else.

[10:57:05.0000] <ezyang>
Which is why I'm planning on swapping out most of my code for html5lib when the PHP impl gets stable enough 

[10:59:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Basically, I think what you need to do is parsing the input stream, remove elements/attributes on whitelist, remove some more attributes based upon their value, then serialize, quoting attribute values.

[10:59:01.0000] <gsnedders>
I think that should get you security.

[11:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and remove comments)

[11:01:00.0000] <ezyang>
gsnedders: I argue that removing attributes based on value is the wrong paradigm (it should be machine-semantic deconstruction of each attribute), but yes, essentially. 

[11:01:01.0000] <ezyang>
And remove comments, yep. 

[11:01:02.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: What's the difference?

[11:01:03.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: That is, ultimately, just inspecting the value. No?

[11:02:00.0000] <ezyang>
Semantic deconstruction means that attribute values might change. 

[11:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
The html5lib sanitiser has e.g. a regexp for detecting 'safe' style attribute values, and throws out any attribute that doesn't match, I think

[11:02:02.0000] <ezyang>
Canonicalization of a URL or CSS string is more important 

[11:02:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[11:02:04.0000] <gsnedders>

[11:20:00.0000] <ezyang>
Ok, so here's what's going to happen. HTML Purifier 5.0 will be able to operate as "make it valid omgwtf" and "make it secure" 

[11:21:00.0000] <ezyang>

[11:21:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[12:17:00.0000] <JoePeck>
Hello.  Is there any way to access the current page's response headers via Javascript, like you can access an AJAX Requests response headers (with xhr.getAllResponseHeaders etc).  And if not, why not or was it just not thought of?

[12:19:00.0000] <JoePeck>
Since you can just spawn an AJAX request for the current page, and get the headers that way, I think it should be allowable for Javascript to have access to the response headers of the current page.  At least I can't think of a realistic security concern.

[12:35:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
JoePeck: As far as I know you can't and I agree. It is an oversight.

[12:36:00.0000] <JoePeck>
Hmm, should I make a formal email to the mailing list?

[12:39:00.0000] <mookid>
no

[12:39:01.0000] <mookid>
the response is the response

[12:40:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
Scripts should be able to resolve things such as relative URIs if the HTTP header "Content-Base" is used. We shouldn't have to use meta or base tags for that.

[12:40:01.0000] <JoePeck>
mookid: but the headers aren't available to Javascript?

[12:40:02.0000] <mookid>
the client side doesn't, and shouldn't, be able to modify the response - it just is what it is

[12:40:03.0000] <gsnedders_>
ezyang: Yes, email. You know these things?

[12:40:04.0000] <JoePeck>
mookid: not modify, access.  What about custom headers?

[12:41:00.0000] <JoePeck>
not that it would make any sense to modify the response headers... they are the response headers =)

[12:43:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
Out of curiousity, what headers would you like to access? Custom only?

[12:44:00.0000] <JoePeck>
sebmarkbage: actually, someone in ##javascript wanted to access the "Date" header sent from his server

[12:44:01.0000] <JoePeck>
but I could think of accessing the Content-Type and custom headers

[12:44:02.0000] <JoePeck>
as possible use cases

[12:44:03.0000] <mookid>
wait - what

[12:45:00.0000] <JoePeck>
mookid: it seems I have a difficult time explaining this because everyone seems to respond with a "what?" =(

[12:45:01.0000] <mookid>
you can't read response headers?

[12:45:02.0000] <JoePeck>
Here was my example page: http://bogojoker.com/x/xhr/headers.html

[12:46:00.0000] <JoePeck>
you can read the response headers, but only for an AJAX Request

[12:46:01.0000] <sebmarkbage>
You can read response headers off of XHR but not for the current document.

[12:46:02.0000] <JoePeck>
exactly

[12:46:03.0000] <sebmarkbage>
I.e. you'd have to make another request to find that out.

[12:46:04.0000] <JoePeck>
sebmarkbage++ thanks =)

[12:47:00.0000] <mookid>
yeah well that's a good example of what a ridiculously poor HTTP client most browsers are

[12:47:01.0000] <mookid>
you'll get the "we need a use case" nonsense

[12:48:00.0000] <takkaria>
...

[12:48:01.0000] <mookid>
the reality is that they didn't read the RFC properly

[12:48:02.0000] <JoePeck>
well, why get the response headers from an ajax request?  If there was a use case for that then they all apply for this case as well

[12:48:03.0000] <takkaria>
you can be a perfectly good HTTP client without exposing request headers to JavaScript

[12:49:00.0000] <mookid>
browsers are crap HTTP clients

[12:49:01.0000] <JoePeck>
I agree with takkaria on that

[12:49:02.0000] <JoePeck>
mookid: and what would you suggest as a good HTTP client?

[12:49:03.0000] <takkaria>

[21:37:00.0000] <boblet>
MikeSmith:  does the spec explicitly state that things like incorrect nesting are wrong? I could only find nesting mentioned in an error handling example…

[21:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
boblet: no, not about incorrect nesting specifically

[21:40:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I don't know what you'd classify as other things like incorrect nesting

[21:41:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
boblet: lemme qualify that statement

[21:41:01.0000] <boblet>
The good coding practices that were taught via XHTML—closing elements, not dropping optional elements that add meaning etc

[21:41:02.0000] <boblet>
non-tag soup stuff

[21:41:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
those are best practices, not errors

[21:42:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
misnested tags are a real error

[21:42:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
a parsing error

[21:42:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
not dropping optional elements is a best practice

[21:42:03.0000] <boblet>
aah ok. but neither are currently mentioned right?

[21:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
those best-practice things, no

[21:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
IMHO, those are not appropriate for the spec

[21:43:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
but should just be in authoring guides instead

[21:43:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
in particular, closing elements for which the end tag is not required is an optional authoring choice

[21:43:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
in the case of the HTML syntax

[21:43:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
in the XHTML syntax, it is a parse error

[21:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
because end tags are always required in XHTML

[21:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, either that or self-closing start tags

[21:44:02.0000] <boblet>
ok—thanks for the clarification

[21:44:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
about misnested tags in particular

[21:44:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
the spec does not explicitly define what misnested tags are 

[21:45:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or define what misnesting of tags is

[21:45:01.0000] <boblet>
the old <b><i></b></i> chestnut is in 9.2.8

[21:45:02.0000] <boblet>
but only as an example

[21:45:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
what it does say explicitly is, "an elements contents must be contained within the element's start tag and end tag"

[21:45:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
or something very similar to that

[21:46:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
(despite the quotes, I'm paraphrasing from memory)

[21:46:01.0000] <boblet>
heh, was gonna ask you for a reference there

[21:46:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie reckons that statement is clear enough. but IMHO it could be clearer

[21:46:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
see the Writing HTML documents section

[21:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/syntax.html#elements-0

[21:48:01.0000] <boblet>
got it

[21:48:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
"The contents of the element must be placed between just after the start tag (which might be implied, in certain cases) and just before the end tag (which again, might be implied in certain cases)."

[21:49:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but if you have some specific proposed text that you think would make it more clear, that would be great

[21:49:01.0000] <Hixie>

[21:49:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[21:50:01.0000] <Hixie>

cool

[21:50:03.0000] <boblet>

[21:50:05.0000] <Hixie>

[21:54:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
true

[21:54:01.0000] <boblet>

[21:57:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[21:57:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
"scope creep"

[21:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
start out with a small, focused information need, then add enough people, next thing you're doing is project SpaceX 

[21:59:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
building a rocket ship to the moon

[21:59:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it's not just in standards development, actually

[22:00:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
in my experience in product development, it's pretty much the same with functional specs

[22:00:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
especially if you involve the customer

[22:00:02.0000] <boblet>
well, everyone wants more

[22:00:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, I guess so

[22:00:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
you solve that problem by not trying to make everybody happy

[22:01:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
by realizing that you *can't* make everybody happy

[22:01:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and instead try to get done what's actually most important and most necessary

[01:13:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:13:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:14:00.0000] <Hixie>

[01:17:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:18:01.0000] <tyoshino>

[01:18:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:19:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
well there are two ways one could integrate this with apache

[01:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
for the IM case

[01:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
either you could have a dedicated apache module that, after the handshake, does exactly what the dedicated IM server we just talked about would do

[01:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
or, you have an apache module that is someone like the CGI module, in that after the handshake, it hands the socket over to some other script, and that script does the chatting back and forth

[01:32:00.0000] <boblet>
Hey all, can anyone tell me the WhatWG stance on role, either the ARIA or the ‘bestowing semantics’ variety?

[01:32:01.0000] <takkaria>
I'm not sure there is a WHATWG "stance" per se

[01:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
ARIA is scheduled to get merged into HTML5 whenever the ARIA group are done dealing with their last call comments adequately

[01:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
(er "merged" in the sense that it will be conforming to use ARIA in HTML5 - i don't expect to copy the text in verbatim or anything)

[01:33:02.0000] <boblet>
ok

[01:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
(i expect it'll just be a list of attributes, a list of constraints on when they can be used, and a reference to the ARIA author and implementor specs)

[01:34:01.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: any idea if that will be eg in time for October?

[01:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
no idea

[01:34:03.0000] <tantekc>
Hixie, what are your standards for "merged" in the sense of conforming to use and referencing external specs rather than copying the text in verbatim etc.?

[01:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
dunno, it hasn't come up before :-)

[01:37:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: what about the ‘using role for adding semantic meaning’ idea? I’m guessing there’s a reason for <nav> rather than <ul role="nvaigation">…

[01:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
how is it different to class=""?

[01:41:00.0000] <boblet>
I’m guessing because the semantic meanings are formally and officially defined, and that implementors then add support for these meanings where appropriate

[01:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
oh. then how is it different to elements?

[01:43:00.0000] <boblet>
I guess because then the semantics can be applied to more than one element, depending on which one was most appropriate

[01:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
isn't that just like nesting?

[01:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
i don't really understand the problem this would solve

[01:46:00.0000] <boblet>
I’m personally happy with the whole new elements approach—I think it’s conceptually simpler to add a few new elements than use div with role (or class) for everything, and easier to teach. I’m trying to understand the difference between John Allsopp’s approach and adding new elements.

[01:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
one difference is it that elements can be further subclassed

[01:48:01.0000] <boblet>
It certainly seems like the Microformats approach has paid off in faster implementation for the problems they’ve addressed, so I can see the logic to role being more amenable to rapid changes vs adding new elements

[01:48:02.0000] <boblet>
hey Mike

[01:48:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
hey

[01:48:04.0000] <boblet>
by subclassed are you meaning with classes or with nesting?

[01:48:05.0000] <tantek>
boblet - indeed.

[01:49:00.0000] <tantek>
after the experience with microformats and the ability to assign *multiple* semantics to a single element, it's pretty clear to me that the one element = one tag = one meaning design of SGML/HTML/XML is fundamentally flawed.

[01:49:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
boblet: if you used <div class=section> for bunch of sections and then you want to to further distinguish between kinds of sections, you don't have a class attribute to use to subclass them any more

[01:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: depends what you're solving, but yes

[01:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: if we were designing a new markup language from scratch, this would be a good discussion to have :-)

[01:50:01.0000] <tantek>
space separated set of class names for semantics has provided far better flexibility in terms of more easily marking up content that web authors actually publish.

[01:50:02.0000] <boblet>
MikeSmith: well only if you’re using IE6 ;-)

[01:50:03.0000] <tantek>
MikeSmith - not true - you can add additional class names to provide additional semantics in your class="section" example.

[01:51:00.0000] <boblet>
woops, I think I might have started something :)

[01:51:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
boblet: tantek's right, I'm wrong. :)

[01:52:00.0000] <boblet>
MikeSmith: well, as I said you’re right for IE6 (and CSS styling)—it only sees the first (or was it last?) class name

[01:52:01.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, I asked the above question (re: reference vs. wholly incorporate) because I am revising hCard, hCalendar, hReview, hAtom with bug fix revisions that incorporate numerous issue resolutions (including your issue regarding conformance criteria for user-agents and authors).

[01:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
if authors want to do <div class="section something"> instead of using <section class="something">, the existence of a <section> element does not prevent them from doing that

[01:54:00.0000] <tantek>
e.g. hCard 1.0.1, hCalendar 1.0.1. - at that point I'm confident that those specifications will be more thorough, and incorporate more issue resolutions than the corresponding pre-defined microdata vocabularies of vcard/vevent.

[01:55:00.0000] <tantek>
not to mention be backed by actual experience from numerous authors publishing hCards and hCalendar events as defined.

[01:56:00.0000] <tantek>
and thus it should be reasonable to consider incorporating hCard and hCalendar vocabularies by *reference* rather by redefinition inline in the HTML5 spec.

[01:57:00.0000] <boblet>
MikeSmith: I think that web authors perceive class as an ad hoc system, rather than something official. While Microformats have pushed it a long way, I think that a W3-defined vocabulary of semantics (either new elements or role values) are far more official. Also I’m guessing implementors would feel the same—they’d be more likely to build functionality on something that’s defined (by W3) rather than something that’s just

[01:57:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
boblet: you got cut off there

[01:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: i think we're actually going to take out the few vocabularies that are in there already (the vcard and vevent ones, and the licensing works one)

[01:58:01.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, this is just a heads up of work in progress. I will re-raise the issue when hCard 1.0.1 and hCalendar 1.0.1 drafts have been published. In either case, I do think it is premature/unwise to include pre-defined microdata vocabularies.  Hopefully the updates to hCard and hCalendar will make that even more clear.

[01:58:02.0000] <boblet>
too wordy—my bad. how far?

[01:58:03.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: and put them in their own specs

[01:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: i haven't worked out what should happen reference-wise

[01:58:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
to "that's jus..."

[01:58:06.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: it might be that we end up with a section that mentions vocabularies that use various features like class="" (assuming microformats continue to use those instead of item/itemprop) and item/itemprop

[01:58:07.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: in a non-normative way

[01:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: in which case i'd be happy to link to some normative definitions if there are some

[01:59:01.0000] <boblet>
RT: Also I’m guessing implementors would feel the same—they’d be more likely to build functionality on something that’s defined (by W3) rather than something that’s just agreed (by users of Microformats etc)

[01:59:02.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, the licensing works one will take more effort because it requires completion of the in-progress "licensing microformat", however it will very likely have similar to features to what you've written up - as you seem to have come to many of the same conclusions as the licensing microformats brainstorming efforts.

[01:59:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
boblet: but none of us want something official if it overly restricts authors. the point is to try to find some kind of sweet spot. to provide more authoring ease without locking people into something official that ends up restricting and confusing them too much

[02:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: that's no coincidence, the microformats wiki was one of my main crib sheets :-)

[02:01:00.0000] <tantek>
we do seem to agree that the ccREL as designed is problematic due to it's ability/encouragement for license proliferation, which IMHO is a fatal design flaw. http://microformats.org/wiki/licensing-brainstorming#ccREL_issues

[02:02:00.0000] <tantek>
s/it's/its duh

[02:02:01.0000] <boblet>
MikeSmith: well, I think new elements could also be considered fairly restrictive (in terms of number and release cycle)

[02:03:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, that is good to hear that the pre-defined vocabularies will be taken out of the HTML5 spec.

[02:03:01.0000] <boblet>
That’s why the potential of eg role values being defined in a Microformats-like way but by WhatWG/W3 seems really interesting—official and well-thought-out like elements, but faster release cycle like µF

[02:03:02.0000] <tantek>
As far as microformats use of class vs. item/itemprop, it is likely that for the forseeable future microformats will continue to make use of the class attribute for backwards compatibility.

[02:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
as an implementor, I don't have a problem in principle implementing things based on microformats, just because they are not W3C-official or whatever

[02:04:01.0000] <tantek>
However, I believe it does make sense to advocate use of HTML5's features when authors are able to do so (are able to depend on them based on their use cases), and it is more advantageous to do so.

[02:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the main problems with microformats (neither completely fatal) are that parsing has historically not been defined very tightly, and the trickiness of figuring out the right browser UI to expose them

[02:05:01.0000] <tantek>
This will likely be an extension of the "How to use microformats in HTML5" work in development, that advocates use of the <time> element etc.

[02:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(from a browser implementor perspective)

[02:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one thing I like about microdata is that it takes you from parsing to a data model in a precisely defined way

[02:06:01.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej, I will encourage you to review the hCard 1.0.1 and hCalendar 1.0.1 drafts regarding the thoroughness of parsing definition. it is my intent to make those definitions thorough through both prose and test cases.

[02:06:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so microdata-based formats could start defining things at the data model level

[02:07:00.0000] <tantek>
I agree, the parsing to data model description of the general microdata feature is quite admirable.

[02:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: I did say "historically", cause I haven't reviewed recently

[02:07:02.0000] <tantek>
(btw parsing details are a known issue that I've resolved as needing additional work for hCard 1.0.1 and hCalendar 1.0.1)

[02:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one other thing I like about microdata is that it exposes the data model through a nice DOM API, which is friendly to data extraction via client-side script or client-side logic in general

[02:09:00.0000] <tantek>
we are doing something similar in microformats for our recent test-suite update efforts: http://microformats.org/wiki/test-suite

[02:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hCard and hCalendar are probably among the microformats that are most interesting for likely built-in browser features, if anyone ever goes there

[02:10:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I would really like to support hAtom as well, but that probably won't happen unless our feed parsing code is open sourced and a motivated individual can take matters into their own hands

[02:12:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej - does it help that there is existing open source XSLT that you can incorporate to transform hAtom to Atom and then just pipe that into your existing support? http://rbach.priv.at/Microformats/hAtom2Atom/

[02:12:01.0000] <tantek>
specifically, available under the The W3C Open Source License per http://rbach.priv.at/Microformats/hAtom2Atom/readme.txt

[02:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: I expect HTML's release cycle to be remarkably quicker once HTML5 is done

[02:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
tantek: the people who originally wrote our support are no longer with the company and left a... very creative combination of diverse technologies that... provides an intellectual puzzle for those of us on the team

[02:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so it doesn't actually help that much directly, but thanks for the reference

[02:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: the main problem with HTML that made HTML5 take so long was the utterly woeful state of the HTML and DOM HTML specifications prior to HTML5, in terms of conformance criteria for implementors (of all classes, not just browsers), and in terms of missing features altogether (DOM level 0 in particular)

[02:14:01.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej - that's too bad. perhaps as you say you can open sourcce the feed parsing code as part of WebKit and thus enable folks to improve it.

[02:14:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think open sourcing the code would also likely lead to it being greatly simplified and improved

[02:14:03.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: that makes sense (using class for back compat vs using microdata when it makes sense going forward)

[02:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>
because WebKit has much higher standards for code quality than most Apple-internal code

[02:22:03.0000] <tantek>
(the itemprop="about" thing)

[02:24:00.0000] <tantek>
frankly, I think the whole approach of encouraging the inclusion of invisible hyperlinks in content (what the "about" design does in RDF/RDFa) is fundamentally flawed. the "dark data" problem as it were.

[02:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah. that's why i like itemprop=about -- it encourages people to use <img> or <a href=""> to say what they're talking about

[02:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
i was quite honestly surprised that RDFa really doesn't make the licensing use case as easy as microdata can

[02:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
i sent a mail about that where i showed what i thought the best you could do with RDFa was, and it was surprisingly verbose compared to what i ended up with with microdata

[02:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
including some duplication of data, which violates what i thought was an RDFa design goal (DRY)

[02:32:03.0000] <tantek>

[02:33:00.0000] <tantek>

[02:33:03.0000] <tantek>

[02:33:04.0000] <Hixie>

[02:34:00.0000] <gsnedders|work>

[02:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:34:02.0000] <boblet>

[02:34:03.0000] <tantek>

[02:34:04.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej - believe me, I sympathize with that.

[02:34:05.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: that's unaffected by this, since in practice all the implementation work happens before we get to LC anyway

[02:34:06.0000] <othermaciej>
and it's hard to be confident in an implementation without a thorough test suite, which is also very hard to develop against a constantly evolving snapshot

[02:34:07.0000] <tantek>

[02:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:35:01.0000] <Hixie>

[02:35:02.0000] <tantek>

[02:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but really the challenge for using the spec is not just new features (where naturally you look there first) but rather aligning old implementations of features that used to be in the mutual reverse engineering domain with the spec

[02:36:02.0000] <takkaria>

[02:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
how do you mean?

[02:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
(a bug-fix-only branch of the spec that is)

[02:37:04.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: returning to the elements vs role conversation, while you’re not starting from scratch I perceive HTML5’s structural elements as new as role would be, so I’m still wondering why elements over role

[02:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: oh if we keep adding new features, we'll never get to the point where there are two full impls, sure

[02:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
a version of the spec that only corrects errors, doesn't add new functionality, so that you can go through methodically without it changing out from under you

[02:38:02.0000] <boblet>
are there any advantages of using elements, or conversely are there any disadvantages of using roles?

[02:38:03.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: because <foo> is nicer to type than <z z="foo">

[02:39:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: yep, that’s a good reason

[02:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: if the syntax made it easier to have nodes in the DOM be given multiple labels at once, e.g. if the syntax had <a b c> as equivalent to <c b a> or <b a c> or whatever, that'd be a very different story

[02:39:02.0000] <othermaciej>
software projects pretty commonly have stable and new development branches, rarely ones that live for years, but that is not unprecedented

[02:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: yeah, it may be that that the benefits to implementors are worth the pain to the spec writer :-)

[02:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i've never heard of any project that had a branch that lasted more than about a month where people on the project haven't complained that it was a mistake

[02:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
and i've heard of _many_ such branches

[02:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
WebKit has had stable branches last over a year that we actually shipped off of, but they didn't have direct new development and the longer you go the harder it gets to backport fixes

[02:42:00.0000] <tantek>
othermaciej - indeed, your revising of specs points are good ones.

[02:42:01.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: not sure I understood that :) what about <ul role="aside nav"> vs <aside><nav><ul> for article section links?

[02:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
we didn't really complain about that except to the extent that backporting bug fixes is less fun than new development

[02:42:03.0000] <tantek>
for this reason I'm simultaneously editing an hCard 1.0.1 and hCard 1.1.

[02:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
although the one time we tried feature development based on an old branch - it was hell

[02:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: <aside><nav> is redundant, just use <nav>, but in general i'd say the role="" alternative looks much uglier and doesn't really get you any useful benefits.

[02:43:02.0000] <gsnedders|work>
othermaciej: It'd be nice to have an infinitely large test suite and a no-regressions policy so you could always ship the latest code :)

[02:43:03.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: again, because of the way the DOM works, there are things that are much harder to do if you put the semantics in attributes

[02:43:04.0000] <gsnedders|work>

[02:43:05.0000] <othermaciej>
sadly, our test suite is not yet infinite

[02:44:00.0000] <Hixie>

[02:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
boblet: does it spawn an applet or play audio?

[02:44:02.0000] <Hixie>

[02:44:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:46:03.0000] <gsnedders|work>

[02:46:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:46:05.0000] <gsnedders|work>

[02:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:47:01.0000] <Hixie>

[02:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but I would expect browser-hosted implementations to always make a new node for that

[02:47:03.0000] <Hixie>

[02:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:44:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
I want to ask a question to solve a discussion from #html: If one is abandoning XHTML for a page, should he use the new doctype or an HTML 4 doctype? How do older browsers handle <DOCTYPE html>?

[13:44:01.0000] <Sidnicious>
s/#html/#css/

[13:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
Sidnicious: It makes old browsers render in standards mode (instead of quirks mode)

[13:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
Sidnicious: See e.g. the table near the bottom of http://hsivonen.iki.fi/doctype/

[13:48:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
The people I'm talking to think of HTML 5 as separate from HTML 4, and believe that it's dangerous to use the new doctype until HTML 5 is officially supported by every popular browser

[13:50:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Sidnicious: It is officially supported to some extent in all browsers.

[13:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
Sidnicious: Every popular browser behaves precisely the same if you use <!DOCTYPE html> as if you use e.g. <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd">

[13:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
Sidnicious: (That also works the other way, so you can use HTML5 features like <canvas> and <video> with an HTML4 doctype exactly the same as with the HTML5 doctype)

[13:53:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
Philip`: Great, thank you.

[13:56:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Sidnicious: The only difference is in what is conforming, and what throws a validation error (though almost everything from HTML 4.01 Strict is conforming HTML 5)

[17:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: amusing

[04:23:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me is tempted to do more work on HTTP parsing

[04:31:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Is it sensible to use ABNF but state that alternations must be matched from left to right?

[04:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
gsnedders: yeah, I think it would be. as long as you made that clear in the spec

[04:33:00.0000] <gsnedders>
It means I don't end up with things like: ( [ ":" *LWS ] 1*header-content-nc [ *LWS ":" ] / 1*":" / 1*header-content-nc 1*LWS ":" *LWS header-content [ *( header-content / LWS ) header-content ] ) *LWS

[04:33:01.0000] <gsnedders>
That was an attempt to give everything that doesn't match another rule :)

[04:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
If the order of matching is important, that sounds like a fundamental shift from the usual notion of a language grammar

[04:35:00.0000] <gsnedders>
*( %x00-09 / %x0B-FF ) LF is a lot simpler :)

[04:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
(since normally grammars just define a set of matching strings, and it's irrelevant how you matched it)

[04:36:00.0000] <gsnedders>
The URI spec relies upon such a restraint though

[04:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
It sort of sounds like you want to define a new type of alternative, such that "Rule1 / Rule2" matches if Rule1 matches or else if Rule1 doesn't match and Rule2 does match

[04:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
but that matches exactly the same as the normal type of alternative

[04:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
so I may be misunderstanding what you want

[04:38:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Peh. If anyone complains I'll just say that RFC 3986 and 3987 (URI and IRI respectively) do this too.

[04:38:03.0000] <Philip`>
s/exactly the same/exactly the same set of strings/

[04:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose it makes more sense if you have an unambiguous grammar and you're interested in which rules match

[04:40:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Is there any way to easily work out a rule that represents everything that doesn't match another rule?

[04:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
in which case it seems like the 'correct' thing to do would be to define an AABNF which adds a new unambiguating-alternative rule

[04:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
because then it would be well defined and unambiguous and everything

[09:28:00.0000] <inimino>
gsnedders: what you describe is basically a PEG

[09:29:00.0000] <gsnedders>
a PEG?

[09:29:01.0000] <inimino>
rather than BNF

[09:30:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me points out he isn't a compsci guy

[09:30:01.0000] <takkaria>
gsnedders: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsing_expression_grammar

[09:43:00.0000] <gsnedders>
inimino: I do, however, need something formally defined to enough of an extent to use in a spec.

[09:45:00.0000] <inimino>
PEGs are quite formally defined, but if the protocol is byte-oriented you might want to use the ABNF notation for terminals anyway

[09:45:01.0000] <inimino>
it's fairly common to treat ABNF this way and there are even some parser generators that treat ABNF like something it's not

[09:46:00.0000] <inimino>
technically it's impossible to generate an efficient parser from an ABNF since they can be ambiguous

[09:52:00.0000] <gsnedders>
inimino: Yeah, right, I know.

[13:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
nslater: fixed the "media types" section title; where else are they used interchangeably?

[13:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: thanks, good work

[14:01:00.0000] <nslater>
Hixie: hey, well just poked around whatever documents I could find in google, and I seem to find both being used. shouldn't "media type" be the one you use? MIME is old, and for email. right?

[14:03:00.0000] <nslater>
"An Internet media type,[1] originally called a MIME type after MIME and sometimes a Content-type after the name of a header in several protocols whose value is such a type, is a two-part identifier for file formats on the Internet." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_media_type

[14:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
nslater: the term "media type" is also used for things like "screen" vs "tv" vs "braille" so it would be confusing to (continue to) call MIME types "media types", so that's why we try to use "MIME types" for those

[14:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
(MIME types don't really talk about "media" per se so the term "media type" is very misleading)

[14:12:00.0000] <nslater>
Hixie: that's an interesting point, but at this stage, I think the generally accepted name is media type and it would seem weird to ignore that, especially if that introuces nomenclature discrepencies with the rest of the W3C cannon. is it really that much of an issue? I'm guessing that its meaning can be accurately infered from context. you're not likely to talk about Internet Media Types and @media types in the same sections

[14:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
nslater: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-source-element talks about media types and MIME types in adjacent normative paragraphs

[14:13:01.0000] <nslater>
heh, that was quick!

[14:13:02.0000] <nslater>
/me checks

[14:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
(though it tries to avoid the term "media type" altogether to reduce confusion for precisely this reason)

[14:14:01.0000] <nslater>
wow, that document has caused firefox to grey out under gnome!

[14:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
oh let me send you a link to the multipage version

[14:15:01.0000] <Hixie>
hold on

[14:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/video.html#the-source-element

[14:17:00.0000] <nslater>
hmm, if "media type" was hyperlinked each time, like I see "media resource" is, would that not help? I'm actually strugling to see the other use of media type in this section. can you give me a bit of text to search for? 

[14:18:00.0000] <nslater>
"The media  attribute gives the intended media type of the media resource, to help the user agent determine if this media resource is useful to the user before fetching it. Its value must be a valid media query."

[14:18:01.0000] <nslater>
.. I think that's the bit

[14:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
Right, the type attribute is a MIME type, the media attribute is a media query.

[14:19:00.0000] <nslater>
which could be reworded to "The media  attribute gives the intended type of the media resource" maybe? dunno

[14:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
"media resource"?

[14:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's the media type of the resource

[14:19:03.0000] <Hixie>
i.e. whether it's intended for screen, or projection, or whatever

[14:19:04.0000] <nslater>
I just copied that from the document

[14:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
(the hyperlinking solution would fail in the print copy)

[14:20:01.0000] <nslater>
"The media attribute gives the intended media type of the media resource"

[14:20:02.0000] <nslater>
to:

[14:20:03.0000] <nslater>
"The media attribute gives the intended type of the media resource"

[14:20:04.0000] <Hixie>
what kind of type?

[14:20:05.0000] <Hixie>
media type? MIME type? codec type?

[14:21:00.0000] <nslater>
hmm..

[14:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
anyway. the long and short of it is the word "media type" is being used to mean, well, the kind of media, and the word MIME type is being used for MIME types

[14:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
because that avoids the confusion

[14:21:03.0000] <Hixie>
at least a little

[14:21:04.0000] <Hixie>
i can mention this explicitly in the terminology section if you like

[14:21:05.0000] <nslater>
I notice that IANA uses both at the same time, which really helps:

[14:21:06.0000] <nslater>
http://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/

[14:21:07.0000] <nslater>
heh

[14:21:08.0000] <nslater>
Hixie: yeah, that might be a good idea

[14:23:00.0000] <nslater>
both these documents use "media type" as a section header fwiw:

[14:23:01.0000] <nslater>
http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/video.html#media-types

[14:23:02.0000] <nslater>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html

[14:23:03.0000] <nslater>
there may be more, I didn't check

[14:23:04.0000] <Hixie>
the TR page is obsolete, don't worry about that

[14:23:05.0000] <nslater>
sure

[14:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
the only remaining mention of "media type" in the other one is talking about media types

[14:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
not mime types

[14:25:00.0000] <nslater>
okay cool

[14:27:00.0000] <nslater>
thanks for the feedback too, didn't know if irc was appropriate for minor comments

[14:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's ok, e-mail is preferred if you want it to definitely be responded to :-)

[14:31:00.0000] <nslater>
:p

[14:37:00.0000] <Philip`>

[14:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think my record is about 4 years

[14:38:01.0000] <Hixie>

[14:41:00.0000] <Hixie>

it turns out that sicking's description of what happens with innerHTML and defer scripts and document.write() in IE is slightly wrong

[18:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
what's actually going on is that setting innerHTML on a node in the document is causing the pending deferred scripts to be run right there

[18:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
and if there are any deferred scripts that haven't loaded yet... they get dropped completely

[18:36:00.0000] <ojan>
ewww

[18:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah so obviously we can't spec the dropping on the floor bit

[18:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
but it looks like there might be serious compat needs to support the rest of it

[18:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
our options with the dropping on the floor bit are either to execute only <script defer> without src="" there, or to pause there are execute all of them

[18:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
s/are ex/and ex/

[18:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
in the former case, if there's any d.w()s that are being dropped by IE, it would cause the page to blank again

[18:43:03.0000] <Hixie>
so i guess the latter is better

[22:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: are you around?

[14:36:00.0000] <annevk2>
no

[14:37:00.0000] <Darxus>

[14:37:01.0000] <Philip`>

[14:38:00.0000] <Darxus>

[14:38:01.0000] <Philip`>

[14:38:02.0000] <Darxus>

[14:38:03.0000] <Philip`>

[14:42:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[14:42:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: DOCTYPEs are that :P

[14:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
Darxus: If you're using the XML serialisation of HTML 5 (i.e. serving it as application/xhtml+xml, not text/html) you can do whatever you want with the doctype

[14:43:01.0000] <Darxus>
gsnedders: I thought the doctype could only specify a DTD?

[14:43:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: A DTD is a schema.

[14:43:03.0000] <Philip`>
(Only the text/html serialisation requires <!DOCTYPE html>)

[14:44:00.0000] <Darxus>
gsnedders: Ah, so the "DTD" in a DOCTYPE is not specifically the "DTD" schema language?

[14:44:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: It is

[14:44:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: My point is you are linking to a type of schema :P

[14:44:03.0000] <Darxus>
gsnedders: Ah, yes, but DTD has been called "woefully inadequite".  

[14:44:04.0000] <gsnedders>
(which is a DTD)

[14:45:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: Indeed.

[14:45:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: But it's a way of linking to a schema :P

[14:45:02.0000] <Darxus>
gsnedders: Yes, but not a sufficiently useful one :)

[14:45:03.0000] <Philip`>
HTML 5 considers the entire concept of schema languages to be woefully inadequate

[14:45:04.0000] <Philip`>
except when the language is English :-)

[14:45:05.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: There's some way of linking to XSD files, but XSD is horrid.

[14:45:06.0000] <Philip`>
...or Java

[14:45:07.0000] <Darxus>

[14:46:00.0000] <Darxus>

[14:46:01.0000] <inimino>

[14:46:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[14:46:04.0000] <inimino>

[14:46:05.0000] <annevk2>

[14:47:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Darxus: It means it'll be able to express the constraints

[14:47:01.0000] <gsnedders>
annevk2: Have we proven this?

[14:47:02.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: It means it'll be able to express the machine-checkable constraints

[14:47:03.0000] <annevk2>
(well, apart from the silly SHOULD requirement which requires solving the halting problem)

[14:47:04.0000] <Darxus>
annevk2: Thank you.

[14:47:05.0000] <inimino>
a DTD is formally incapable of expressing some of the machine-checkable conformance criteria

[14:47:06.0000] <Philip`>
where machine-checkable is defined as anything that can be expressed in a Turing-complete language

[14:47:07.0000] <inimino>
Perl isn't, so that's your answer

[14:48:00.0000] <Darxus>
Yeah, that SHOULD is freaking awesome.

[14:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
(where the input is just the document, and no extra state about e.g. the author's brain)

[14:48:02.0000] <gsnedders>
I still want to know how we get a computer to take a deep breath

[14:48:03.0000] <Darxus>
'This is only a "SHOULD" and not a "MUST" requirement because it has been proven to be impossible.'

[14:48:04.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: Put the fans into reverse

[14:54:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Dashiva: That has a schema. That's not a no-schema validator.

[14:54:01.0000] <Darxus>
Ahh.

[14:54:02.0000] <annodomini>
Remember, there is a subset of HTML5 that's checkable with a schema.

[14:54:03.0000] <Darxus>
annodomini: Oh?

[14:55:00.0000] <annodomini>
You can probably do something good enough for the "what tags am I allowed to insert"

[14:55:01.0000] <annodomini>
Or, sorry. Not a subset of HTML5, but a subset of the rules in HTML5 are checkable with a schema.

[14:55:02.0000] <Philip`>
Darxus: When your code is like "function validate_div(node) { ...some function calls to check children are the correct type... }" you can't automatically invert the code to find a list of what types are allowed - all you can do is execute the code

[14:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
so either you need to explicitly write the list of what element types are allowed, or you need to write some kind of schema that can be analysed to compute approximately the right answer

[14:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think that's a rubbish explanation and probably untrue, but never mind

[14:58:01.0000] <Darxus>
Er, schemas don't include a list of what elements may be children / decendants of other elements?  (I noticed the HTML 4.01 didn't, which seemed strange.)

[14:59:00.0000] <gsnedders>
They do

[10:59:00.0000] <Darxus>
Why wasn't CSS originally implimented in sgml, and why isn't it now conformant to xml similarly to HTML5/XML?

[11:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
Because if the syntax was SGML/XML, it would be incredibly painful to write

[11:03:00.0000] <ttepass->
DSSSL!

[11:12:00.0000] <Darxus>
<css> <definition> <target> <element>div</element> <class>container</class> </target> <attribute> <top>0</top> <left>0</left> <width>100%</width> </attribute> </definition> </css>

[11:12:01.0000] <Darxus>
Philip`: Point taken.

[11:13:00.0000] <Darxus>
Or I guess <attribute top="0" left="0" width="100%">.

[11:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
<style selector="div.foo" top="0" left="0" width="100%"/>

[11:14:01.0000] <Darxus>
Wow, thanks.  I have much to learn.

[11:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
if you don't mind using a custom non-XML language for selectors

[11:15:01.0000] <Philip`>
There's nothing to learn, I just made that up :-)

[11:15:02.0000] <Philip`>
Don't know how to extend it to handle things like !important

[11:15:03.0000] <Darxus>
I disagree.  It is a much shorter valid xml way of representing the same thiing I typed.

[11:16:00.0000] <Darxus>

[11:17:00.0000] <eighty4>

[11:20:00.0000] <ttepass->

[11:20:01.0000] <ttepass->

[11:34:00.0000] <tantek>
Darxuz - see http://bytes.com/groups/css/99746-why-css-not-xml

[11:37:00.0000] <tantek>
and while looking for that, I found:

[11:37:01.0000] <tantek>
http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/2004/xhtml-faq

[11:38:00.0000] <tantek>
I'm pretty sure I read this long ago in the past, but I thought folks here might find it insightful from a development of HTML/XHTML standpoint.

[11:39:00.0000] <tantek>
even better answer to the "Why is CSS not XML syntax" FAQ:

[11:39:01.0000] <tantek>
"CSS has its own syntax because readability is very important for a language that is used by nearly as many people as HTML itself. It could have been based on SGML, and originally there were indeed proposals for SGML-based syntaxes (see [Lie99]) and there even existed a US military standard ([FOSI]), but there was never any question that CSS syntax is better. (XML didn't exist at the time, but it wouldn't have helped since it is more verbose than SGML and al

[11:39:02.0000] <tantek>
from http://www.w3.org/People/Bos/DesignGuide/readability.html

[11:39:03.0000] <tantek>
by Bert Bos, one of the creators of CSS

[11:40:00.0000] <inimino>
well put

[11:46:00.0000] <Darxus>
Cool.

[16:26:00.0000] <caden>
is there a way to save the current canvas bitmap and then retrieve it, like to reset the background of an animation?

[16:27:00.0000] <caden>
getImageData, probably?

[16:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
caden: You could create a new <canvas> (with createElement) and then drawImage the current one into it, then draw it back later

[16:27:02.0000] <Philip`>
or use getImageData/putImageData

[16:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
or use toDataURL/drawImage (except that probably will throw security errors in most browsers if you do it multiple times)

[16:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Copying to a new canvas is probably going to be more efficient than getImageData, if you care about that)

[16:30:00.0000] <caden>
can i make that new canvas invisible then?

[16:31:00.0000] <caden>
right now redrawing the graph between animation frames is the application bottleneck

[16:31:01.0000] <caden>
i am hoping i can just refresh this snapshot instead of redrawing all the axes and lines and whatnot

[16:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yes - if you do something like "var c = document.createElement('canvas'); c.width = ...; c.height = ...; c.getContext('2d').drawImage(othercanvas, 0, 0)" then the new canvas never gets rendered since it's not added to the document

[16:35:00.0000] <caden>
i will try it, the get/put did not improve performance

[16:42:00.0000] <caden>
does this look right to ou for restoring the image?  this.snapshotCanvas.getContext('2d').drawImage(this.canvasContext,0,0);

[16:42:01.0000] <caden>
or is this.canvasContext supposed to be a refernce to an element instead of a context

[16:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
caden: The argument to drawImage is the canvas object that you want to copy from

[16:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
rather than a context

[16:45:02.0000] <caden>
ok

[16:45:03.0000] <caden>
thank you!

[16:45:04.0000] <caden>
it looks like it stores the background as transparent, does that sound right?

[16:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
Probably - if you're not explicitly drawing over the canvas's background then it'll just be transparent

[16:46:01.0000] <caden>
cool

[16:56:00.0000] <caden>
well, i'm using a very primitive way of profiling, using just getTime() statements, and these indicate that drawImage is much faster than get/put

[16:57:00.0000] <caden>
although subjectively it doesn't seem faster

[16:57:01.0000] <caden>
maybe it is just my sucky machine

[17:15:00.0000] <shepazu>
Hixie: do elements in HTML5 have "default actions"?

[17:20:00.0000] <shepazu>
ok, I'll try again... anyone, do elements in HTML5 have "default actions"?

[17:20:01.0000] <shepazu>
or is that nonsense?

[17:23:00.0000] <annevk4>
shepazu, they have activation behavior

[17:24:00.0000] <annevk4>
shepazu, e.g.  the activation behavior of <a> is to navigate

[17:25:00.0000] <shepazu>
annevk4: ok... so, is that the terminology of HTML5, HTML4, both...?

[17:26:00.0000] <shepazu>
and if link is activated, what events does it produce?

[17:26:01.0000] <annevk4>
activation behavior is associated with the click event

[17:26:02.0000] <shepazu>
does it produce a click, or only if it was activated by the mouse?

[17:26:03.0000] <shepazu>
/me writes a test

[17:26:04.0000] <annevk4>
always click

[17:27:00.0000] <annevk4>
anyway, the idea was for DOM3Events to define activation behavior and various related thingies, but bjoern never got around to it so now it's defined in HTML5

[17:30:00.0000] <shepazu>
well, I'm actively editing DOM3 Events, so I'll define it there if it needs to be

[17:31:00.0000] <annevk4>
cool

[17:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
shepazu: I think to support "click" and "DOMActivate" the way other browsers do, for elements that have an activation behavior, clicking needs to dispatch a "click" event whose default action is to dispatch a "DOMActivate" event, whose default action in turn is to perform the activation behavior of the element

[17:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
shepazu: similarly, any activation not driven by the mouse (such as via keyboard or by calling the click() method) needs to dispatch a synthetic "click" event same as above

[17:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
shepazu: if DOM3EV defines all this, then HTML5 could limit itself to stating which elements have activation behavior, and what that behavior is for each one

[17:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(I think)

[17:35:00.0000] <annevk4>
yeah, that is pretty much how HTML5 does it

[17:35:01.0000] <annevk4>
I still think we should nuke DOMActivate  though

[17:36:00.0000] <shepazu>
what would change your mind?

[17:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
DOMActivate adds code complexity, and it's not clear if it serves a useful purpose

[17:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
otoh now that we've implemented it, it's not a huge burden to maintain support

[17:37:02.0000] <shepazu>
othermaciej: do you think it would be useful for D3E to define it? I guess if it did, I reckon I'd more or less take whatever HTML5 says on it

[17:38:00.0000] <shepazu>
it would be useful for e.g. SVG, I think

[17:38:01.0000] <annevk4>
shepazu, a good reason for having it besides click?

[17:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
shepazu: I think it makes sense to define the notion of activation in D3E, because I think all specs with activation behavior would want to do it the same

[17:40:00.0000] <shepazu>
ok, I'll put that in an upcoming draft, thanks

[17:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk4: does Opera support DOMActivate?

[17:41:00.0000] <annevk4>
seems like we don't

[17:42:00.0000] <annevk4>
I filed the original bug for it in 2005 or so and all duplicates were from third-party testers

[17:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm wondering how likely it is that any Web content depends on it

[17:42:02.0000] <annevk4>
given the details I have it seems highly unlikely

[17:43:00.0000] <annevk4>
apart from some tests here and there

[17:43:01.0000] <shepazu>
could we find out from MAMA?

[17:43:02.0000] <shepazu>
or from Google's research?

[17:44:00.0000] <annevk4>
we can never be really sure, but both Opera and IE not supporting it seems like a good indicator to me

[17:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
despite what Chaals said, I don't see WCAG specifically requiring DOMActivate

[17:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk4: it's possible sites could be using it in non-IE code paths and not caring or knowing that they break in Opera, although there doesn't seem much reason to doing it

[17:47:01.0000] <Darxus>
The head element says it contains "One or more elements of metadata content, of which exactly one is a title element."

[17:48:00.0000] <annevk4>
othermaciej, I guess

[17:48:01.0000] <annevk4>
othermaciej, I'd be interested in that code :)

[17:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:48:03.0000] <Darxus>

[17:48:04.0000] <othermaciej>
(whether Web-published or not?)

[17:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:57:00.0000] <shepazu>
othermaciej: well, if a circle had a DOMActivate event listener, or maybe a SMIL child element element... but other than that, I don't think any element in SVG should have default "activation behavior" than <a>

[17:57:01.0000] <shepazu>
/me tries to think of what other elements there might be in SVG that have activation behavior...

[17:59:00.0000] <shepazu>
http://www.w3.org/TR/SVGTiny12/elementTable.html

[17:59:01.0000] <shepazu>
