[17:59:02.0000] <annevk4>
elements are activatable based on their event listeners in SVG? ouch

[18:00:00.0000] <annevk4>
oh well, I suppose it does not matter much

[18:02:00.0000] <shepazu>
annevk4: how is it controversial to make an element activateable by putting a "DOMActivate" listener on it? I'm confused...

[18:03:00.0000] <shepazu>
but would the activation behavior of a multimedia element vary on whether the content was already playing or not? what's the activation behavior of HTML multimedia elements?

[18:03:01.0000] <annevk4>
shepazu, it seems activation behavior should come from semantics

[18:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
shepazu: making an element activatable by putting a "DOMActivate" listener on it would be somewhat weird - an ancestor element with a DOMActivate listener would see the inner element get DOMActivate if and only if the inner element had its own listener

[18:05:00.0000] <shepazu>
othermaciej: ok

[18:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
shepazu: since DOMActivate bubbles, that would be somewhat illogical I think

[18:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
also, in general, listeners observe events, but don't observably affect what events get dispatched just by their presence

[18:06:02.0000] <shepazu>
I'm just grasping at straws on what elements in SVG would have inherent activation behavior... links, multimedia elements, maybe SMIL elements that didn't have explicit @begin values?

[18:07:00.0000] <annevk4>
seems like www-svg might be a better place to ask that than #whatwg :)

[18:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you could make the case that every SVG element should be activatable, but it's kind of unclear what forms of non-click activation, if any, would work for something like <circle> or <path>

[18:07:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and what the activation behavior would be

[18:07:03.0000] <Darxus>
I just had an HTML5 comprehension breakthrough.  The "meta" element is in the "encoding declaration state" when its "http-equiv" attribute has a value of "content-type".

[18:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I could buy the argument that an activation-triggered SMIL animation makes you activatable, although that's a complicated rule

[18:08:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think SVG <a> elements are clearly activatable

[18:08:02.0000] <shepazu>
yes, <a> is understood

[18:09:00.0000] <shepazu>
it's not actually a concept that SVG has had to deal with much, since there are so few truly activateable elements, I guess

[18:10:00.0000] <shepazu>
whereas HTML has quite a few

[18:10:01.0000] <Darxus>
Contexts in which the "meta" element can be used really should be changed from "If the charset attribute is present, or if the element is in the Encoding declaration state: in a head element." to 'If the charset attribute is present, or if the attribute "http-equiv" is set to "content-type".'

[18:11:00.0000] <shepazu>
annevk4: are you seriously telling me that I shouldn't try to resolve open questions about improving SVG by asking opinions in #whatwg

[18:12:00.0000] <annevk4>
I thought this was a question about how SVG works today

[18:12:01.0000] <annevk4>
because of "would"

[18:12:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[18:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[18:13:01.0000] <shepazu>
/me looks closer at activation behavior in HTML5, including where it's used

[18:13:02.0000] <annevk4>
shepazu, also, I included a smiley...

[18:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
HTML5 actually defines that any element that is forced to be keyboard focusable by tabIndex is activatable

[18:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(with an activation behavior that does nothing, unless it would otherwise have an activation behavior)

[18:16:02.0000] <shepazu>
yeah, just looking at that

[18:16:03.0000] <shepazu>
ah, ok, thanks, that clarifies it

[18:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and <a>, <label>, <input>, <area>, <command> and <button> may have some built-in activation behavior, depending on circumstances

[18:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
oddly, <bb> does not have defined activation behavior

[18:18:01.0000] <shepazu>
in that case, most SVG elements would have similar behavior for those elements, but still no true activation behavior... maybe it would be more accurate to say that the focusable attribute adds activation behavior

[18:19:00.0000] <shepazu>

[19:22:00.0000] <tantekc>

[19:23:00.0000] <tantekc>
the term "browser button" is already fairly widely used (Google, Technorati, others) as a less jargony replacement for what is otherwise known as a "bookmarklet" or "favelet"

[19:23:01.0000] <tantekc>
http://www.google.com/options/buttons.html

[19:23:02.0000] <tantekc>

[20:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
<bb> is supposed to be a special button for built-in UA functionality that it's generally believed should be restricted to user actions

[20:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so it's somewhat different than <input type="button"> - may have a custom rendering and its behavior is likely different than a normal button

[20:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but I think an element for that particular slice of functionality is overkill

[06:11:00.0000] <zcorpan>
has anyone pointed out that DOMFocusIn bubbles while focus doesn't?

[06:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
zcorpan: I believe it has been mentioned several times

[06:12:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think that makes for a usefully distinct use case

[06:13:00.0000] <annevk4>
there's hardly any use case attached to that though, unless you have event handlers

[06:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
non-bubbling is the sensible behavior for foucs

[06:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
unlike clicks or mouse moves, a child of element X being focused should generally *not* be treated the same as if element X was focused

[06:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(and yes, nested focus is possible and may not even be entirely useless)

[06:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(consider an area that you can keyboard scroll when it has focus, but which contains form controls which can themselves have focus)

[06:15:02.0000] <annevk4>
(or the <video> element)

[06:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the only plausible argument for DOMFocusIn is if content indeed depends on it

[06:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and I think there's no argument whatsoever for standardizing focusin/focusout

[13:18:00.0000] <Darxus>
Hah, HTML5 can't be valid XML because it doesn't allow associating a DTD.  Which is required for valid XML.

[13:21:00.0000] <ttepass->
Darxus, <!DOCTYPE html> is a valid doctype declaration per XML, isn't it?

[13:23:00.0000] <Darxus>
ttepass-: It is a valid doctype, but XML is not valid if it does not specify (and validate with) a DTD.

[13:23:01.0000] <takkaria>
it's still wellformed, though, and you can still validate it. :)

[13:24:00.0000] <ttepass->
Ah: ?Note that it is possible to construct a well-formed document containing a doctypedecl that neither points to an external subset nor contains an internal subset.?

[13:24:01.0000] <Darxus>
"The XML Recommendation says that an XML document is 'valid' if it has an associated document type declaration and if the document complies with the constraints expressed in it."

[13:25:00.0000] <Darxus>
takkaria: Yes you can validate it against another schema but that still, apparently, makes it invalid xml.

[13:25:01.0000] <takkaria>
it doesn't make it invalid

[13:25:02.0000] <Darxus>
Quote from http://perl-xml.sourceforge.net/faq/ section 6.

[13:25:03.0000] <takkaria>
it just means that it's neither valid nor invalid

[13:25:04.0000] <Darxus>
I'm looking for the wording in the XML Recommendation.

[13:26:00.0000] <ttepass->

[13:26:01.0000] <ttepass->

[13:27:00.0000] <Darxus>

[13:27:01.0000] <Darxus>
Yeah...

[13:27:02.0000] <Darxus>
I interpret that as meaning that it is invalid without specifying a DTD.

[13:29:00.0000] <takkaria>

[13:30:00.0000] <takkaria>

[02:09:00.0000] <shepazu>
oh, Hixie, which parts of HTML5 come from XHTML2... is it just some of the sectioning elements?

[02:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
"come from" may be overstating it, but areas where xhtml2 influenced the html5 design include:

[02:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
<section>/<h1>

[02:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
<nav>

[02:10:03.0000] <Hixie>
xforms in general influenced a lot of the webforms 2 additions

[02:10:04.0000] <Hixie>
rdfa influenced microdata a lot

[02:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
<a href=""> being allowed around flow (blocks) was a response of sorts to xhtml2's href=""-everywhere idea

[02:12:00.0000] <shepazu>
what about xforms was reflected in wf2?

[02:12:01.0000] <shepazu>
the data typing...

[02:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
almost all the original wf2 features were basically trying to demonstrate that xforms could be done in text/html

[02:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
so the new controls, the client-side validation

[02:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
some of them didn't make it into html5 proper -- we junked the repetition model, the <select> and <form> autofill

[02:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
various other things

[02:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
in all these cases, xhtml2, xforms, etc, were but some of many other sources of input, which is why i'm being guarded about saying "come from" as such

[02:14:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't mean to minimise their impact on html5

[02:14:02.0000] <shepazu>
sure, I was just being loose with my wording

[02:16:00.0000] <shepazu>
I think I heard that there was more of a direct integration of some XHTML2 (the core language) stuff into HTML5

[02:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
not really. the most direct integration was <section>/<h> which became <section>/<h1>

[02:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think

[02:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
it was so long ago that i may have forgotten some key aspect of xhtml2 that forms the basis of all of html5 :-)

[02:22:00.0000] <shepazu>
heh

[02:22:01.0000] <shepazu>
well, surely it's the distributed extensibility :)

[02:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
nah, we have both forms of that that xhtml2 had, i think

[02:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
at least we have the namespaces and the annotation extensions (through microdata)

[02:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
xhtml2 may have had some m12n extension mechanism that i didn't understand

[02:23:02.0000] <Hixie>
in which case we don't have that

[02:23:03.0000] <Hixie>
from what shane says there's some key part of that that is important in a way i don't follow

[02:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
HTML5 has lots of distributed extensibility - you can describe a feature in an email or blog post or comment or tweet or anything, anywhere on the internet, and Hixie will see it and if it's good then he'll extend the spec to include it

[02:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: I imagined (based on little understanding) the importance was that m12n specified a specific mechanism for specifying a language that's based on XHTML, whereas the HTML5 approach is that you can write your own spec and normatively reference HTML5 (and then get implementers and users to adopt your new spec) and there's no guidance as to how to do that easily or cleanly or safely

[02:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders if that's anywhere even vaguely near correct

[02:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
if that is correct, then it sounds like the kind of extensibility mechanism that we want to avoid... but then again, i apparently missed the memo on extensibility being key to world peace or whatever it is that makes everyone so eager to have it these days

[10:26:02.0000] <Darxus>

[10:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
Darxus: Until recently Firefox didn't even do incremental rendering for XHTML (while it did for HTML); I don't know what differences there are nowadays, but the HTML codepath is likely to have been much more heavily optimised

[10:31:00.0000] <Darxus>
Philip`: So what's the reason for the xml variant of html5?

[10:33:00.0000] <Lachy>
Darxus, because there are a lot of people that want to use XHTML, and it does have some advantages over HTML, depending on the use case

[10:34:00.0000] <Darxus>
What advantages?

[10:34:01.0000] <Darxus>
Is this in the spec?

[10:34:02.0000] <Lachy>
particularly if you want to do a lot of mixed namespace stuff, like embed RDFa or XBL or some other language that isn't (or won't) be natively supported in HTML

[10:34:03.0000] <Philip`>
Darxus: Being fragile hurts non-IE users because of things like http://annevankesteren.nl/2005/11/draconian

[10:36:00.0000] <Lachy>
it also has a lot of advantages as an authoring format, for use on the back end of a CMS, such as being able to integrate with XML tool chains more easily (though you can do that to some extent with HTML too)

[10:38:00.0000] <Darxus>
Philip`: I am entirely comfortable with that situation.

[16:29:00.0000] <deltab>

[16:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
So I'm not allowed to write <p>Hello</p> in XML, because I've omitted the <i> tags and <b> tags etc? :-)

[16:31:01.0000] <gsnedders>
But there's an infinite number of possible tags!

[16:31:02.0000] <deltab>
you don't have any b or i elements there, so you don't need their tags

[16:31:03.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose the accurate thing to say is that XML will not create any elements unless you explicitly give their tags

[16:32:00.0000] <gsnedders>
deltab: Then that's "any tags for whose elements exist", not "any tags"

[16:32:01.0000] <deltab>
if you have an element, you must have either a start tag and an end tag, or an empty-element tag

[16:32:02.0000] <gsnedders>
deltab: Both myself and Philip` are well aware of this.

[16:32:03.0000] <Philip`>

[16:32:04.0000] <deltab>
I should hope so :-) it's for darxus

[16:33:00.0000] <gsnedders>
And then get something which you can't serialize in HTML!

[16:33:01.0000] <Philip`>
(which also omits the corresponding element, as a side effect)

[16:33:02.0000] <Philip`>
so the concept of "omit" gets a little bit fuzzy when comparing HTML and XHTML

[02:51:02.0000] <Lachy>

[02:53:00.0000] <tantek>

[02:54:00.0000] <tantek>

[02:59:00.0000] <tantek>

[15:41:03.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: is there a way to override the class name of an interface? I have two HTMLCollection interfaces that are different but apparently need to both be HTMLCollection objects.

[15:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
not sure what should happen if you override HTMLCollection itself

[15:43:00.0000] <annevk2>
can't the implementation of the interface be different?

[15:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
the interface itself is different

[15:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
and in JS, the interfaces _are_ the implementations

[15:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
since they have prototypes

[15:59:00.0000] <annevk2>
not quite, we can have both static and a live NodeList

[16:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I don't think it makes sense to have the same interface object for interfaces with different methods

[16:01:01.0000] <annevk2>
and if you change namedItem to always return an Object...

[16:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: no disagreement from me there

[16:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(I assume this is about having tags() appear on the "all" HTMLCollection but not other HTMLCollections)

[16:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
annevk2: yeah but the .item() method on the static one is the same as the .item() method on the live one, which isn't the case with these collections

[16:02:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: yes

[16:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the only sensible way to do it is to make HTMLAllCollection a derived interface, is there a reason that would be a compatibility issue?

[16:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(of course the other alternative is to just leave tags() on all HTMLCollections)

[16:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
right now i've done both. We have two interfaces, and .tags() is on both.

[16:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
(there are other differences)

[16:07:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie, why have .tags() on all HTMLCollections?

[16:07:01.0000] <Hixie>
because most browsers have it on all HTMLCollection objects

[16:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
see the mail i just sent to the list

[16:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: is the return of namedItem the other difference?

[16:11:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I can imagine it might be a problem for HTMLCollection and HTMLAllCollection to have no inheritence relationship at all

[16:11:02.0000] <Hixie>
and the implementation of .namedItem, yeah

[16:11:03.0000] <Hixie>
why?

[16:11:04.0000] <Hixie>
the other collection interfaces have no relationship either

[16:11:05.0000] <Hixie>
there's five of them at this point

[16:11:06.0000] <Hixie>
they're all basically the same with weird minor differences

[16:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't know that it is a problem for sure, but if someone wants to prototype-hack HTMLCollection to add or modify a method, it won't work on the unrelated types of collection

[16:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
correct

[16:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
i don't see any way around that given that the prototypes would have different .namedItem()s anyway

[16:12:03.0000] <othermaciej>
so if that works in browsers currently, it could be a compat issue

[16:12:04.0000] <Hixie>
i guess we'll find out

[16:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you could just make namedItem() return Object and not worry about the fact that for some collections it's a more specific type

[16:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
the implementation is still different

[16:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
so the prototype needs to be different

[16:13:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that's irrelevant to the interface

[16:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
not in JS?

[16:14:01.0000] <othermaciej>
the prototype doesn't need to be different

[16:14:02.0000] <othermaciej>
we can have a single JS wrapper that can wrap multiple underlying C++ classes with different behavior

[16:14:03.0000] <Hixie>
so there's only one namedItem() implementation, and it just happens to act very differently in different contexts?

[16:14:04.0000] <othermaciej>
the JS method just needs to call a C++ virtual method

[16:14:05.0000] <Hixie>
freaky

[16:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm thinking of adding an event to WebSocket that fires when the buffers are filling too fast

[16:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
what should i call it?

[16:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
websocket.onoverflow ?

[16:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
websocket.onthrottle ?

[16:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
websocket.on... ?

[16:26:00.0000] <franksalim>
Hixie, the send buffer? or both buffers? the recv buffer must be taken care of by the underlying network layer, right?

[16:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
send

[16:28:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: what's the semantics of this proposed event? does it fire from within send() that will fail?

[16:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
it fires asynchronously whenever the user agent feels like it (when the UA is in danger of hitting some internal limit)

[16:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
unless you have a better idea :-)

[16:30:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: I still think that there needs to be an indication when send() fails

[16:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
you don't know when send fails

[16:31:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: fails to take the data in its queue. sure you know that

[16:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
"take the data in its queue

[16:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
"?

[16:31:03.0000] <ap>
Hixie: here's what TCP guarantees:

[16:31:04.0000] <Hixie>
if you hit a hardware limitation, then you can do whatever you like

[16:31:05.0000] <ap>
Hixie: once you call send(), and it returns success

[16:32:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: it means that either the data will be delivered to the other side

[16:32:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: or no more data will be delivered to the other side over this connection

[16:32:02.0000] <Hixie>
no, it doesn't, except for some definition of "other side" that is not really practically useful to the author.

[16:33:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: huh?

[16:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
what matters is whether the application level on the other side dealt with the data, and the only way you can know that is an acknowledgement.

[16:33:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: I thought I explained it in detail in e-mail :(

[16:33:03.0000] <Hixie>
you can't know from TCP whether the server on the other side is still alive or has had some sort of crash or is spilling all its data on the floor or whatever.

[16:34:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: repeating it again, it means that "either the data will be delivered to the other side, or no more data will be delivered to the other side over this connection"

[16:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
but that's not interesting information

[16:34:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: that may sounds subtle, but it makes all the difference between TCP and UDP

[16:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
i understand the difference between TCP and UDP :-)

[16:35:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: with this guarantee, you can do simple app-level acks

[16:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
sure

[16:35:03.0000] <ap>
Hixie: without it, you need much more complicated mechanisms for acks

[16:35:04.0000] <Hixie>
we already expose "the connection closed"

[16:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't really see what you are proposing

[16:36:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: what I'm saying is that there is absolutely no reason to provide UDP-level reliability when the underlying protocol is TCP

[16:36:02.0000] <Hixie>
ok... we're not doing that

[16:36:03.0000] <Hixie>
so where's the problem?

[16:37:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: that's actually exactly what the spec provides now (well, except that it still guarantees ordering)

[16:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
how so?

[16:37:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: if you call send() several times, and you get an ACK for the last, you cannot be sure that all the data arrived to the other side

[16:37:03.0000] <Hixie>
you can't drop packets in the middle and keep sending them

[16:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
how not?

[16:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
if that's so, there's an error in the spec

[16:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
what text did i screw up?

[16:38:03.0000] <ap>
Hixie: where does the spec say that once packets are dropped, the connection is closed?

[16:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
you're not allowed to drop packets at all.

[16:39:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: oh, do you mean that the current text suggests filling up RAM until it ends?

[16:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
the current spec says that when you call send(), you have to send the bytes.

[16:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
it doesn't say how exactly

[16:39:03.0000] <Hixie>
they just have to be sent

[16:39:04.0000] <Hixie>
there's no permission to not send

[16:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
i can add a line saying "if you can't send, you have to close" if you like

[16:40:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: neither sounds like useful behavior

[16:40:02.0000] <franksalim>
so there is no notion of a send failing

[16:40:03.0000] <Hixie>
ap: neither what?

[16:40:04.0000] <Hixie>
franksalim: not currently

[16:40:05.0000] <franksalim>
if you add a throttling event, there would have to still be a way to indicate that subsequent calls to send failed

[16:40:06.0000] <ap>
Hixie: neither filling up the RAM or closing at UA's discretion

[16:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
ap: what would you like the spec to say?

[16:41:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: as indicated in the mailing list, I like Jeremy Orlow's proposal

[16:42:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: an overflow event that is sent at UA's discretions sounds helpful, too

[16:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
you want send() to throw an exception when the TCP layer failed to successfully send the packet to the other side?

[16:42:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: it's just no substitute

[16:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's what he suggested, but as far as i can tell it's impossible to implement, since send() has to be async.

[16:43:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: actually not, that's not what he suggested

[16:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
ok, so what are you and he proposing, since i misunderstood what he suggested?

[16:44:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: the suggestion is to raise an event when UA no longer wants to buffer the data in its queue (in practice, the buffer will be quite small, to allow for quick adaptation to network conditions)

[16:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
(that's definitely not what he suggested, but ok)

[16:44:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: raqise an exception, sorry

[16:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
so you want send() to throw an exception (but leave the connection open) if the buffer is full?

[16:45:01.0000] <ap>
btw, quoting the suggestion, "Maybe the right behavior is to buffer in user-space (like Maciej explained) up until a limit (left up to the UA) and then anything beyond that results in an exception."

[16:45:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: yes

[16:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
wouldn't that mean send() could arbitrarily and randomly fire exceptions? that seems like a _really_ bad idea

[16:45:04.0000] <Hixie>
and would effectively give you UDP-like behaviour

[16:46:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: I don't agree with either statement (neither that it's bad, nor that it's somehow related to UDP-like behavior)

[16:46:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: returning a boolean result would be as good as firing an exception in my eyes, btw

[16:47:00.0000] <annevk2>
/me doesn't like getAsBinary and getAsBase64

[16:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's bad for the same reason that we are avoiding firing an exception if you call send() on a closed WebSocket

[16:47:02.0000] <ap>
ok, let it be a boolean return value. there just needs to be a clear indication that the data passed to send() is dropped on the floor

[16:47:03.0000] <Hixie>
and it's UDP-like because it means that if you are calling send() on a timer at roughly the rate that you can send, then a random subset of the data will be sent, and the rest will be dropped on the floor.

[16:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
which, as you said earlier, is really bad

[16:48:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: to determine the rate that you can send, one needs guidance

[16:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
sure, so we have the overflow event, which you can use to back off

[16:49:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: back off by how much?

[16:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
(should probably be "willsoonoverflow" or something)

[16:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
who knows

[16:49:04.0000] <Hixie>
a boolean won't tell you either

[16:49:05.0000] <franksalim>
what happens when it actually overflows?

[16:49:06.0000] <ap>
Hixie: there are well established flow control protocols that work with "the boolean"

[16:49:07.0000] <franksalim>
exception? binary value?

[16:49:08.0000] <Hixie>
franksalim: i propose to make the connection close

[16:50:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: like, every streaming protocol that works over TCP can adapt when send() fails

[16:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
ap: yeah, but they're all designed for experts

[16:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
ap: nobody except the experts are going to be checking for a return value from send(), realistically speaking

[16:50:03.0000] <Hixie>
ap: (they're also not going to be checking for an event)

[16:51:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: with 128K or so buffered in the UA, non-experts will still be able to ignore the complexities, and control their toy trains

[16:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm happy to make the event provide more information

[16:51:02.0000] <ap>
Hixie: you're now basically asking experts to come up with new flow control protocols, and non-experts will still not get decent streaming behavior

[16:52:00.0000] <annevk2>
what's the problem with the UA buffering all calls to send() somehow?

[16:52:01.0000] <franksalim>
annevk2, i think all of these proposed behaviors involve doing some amount of buffering

[16:52:02.0000] <ap>
annevk2: the data will never get to the other side if it's sent faster than the network can transmit it

[16:52:03.0000] <Hixie>
ap: i would be ok with returning a number from send() which is how much more data can be buffered, and then failing the connection when you go over the limit

[16:52:04.0000] <franksalim>
but they differ in what to do when a buffer fills

[16:53:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: that sounds good to me, but it is not implementable

[16:53:01.0000] <franksalim>
why fail the connection when you could indicate failure of that particular call to send?

[16:53:02.0000] <annevk2>
ap, the UA can control how fast it is being sent

[16:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
ap: which is similar to what you're suggesting, except that going over (returning false) is fatal

[16:53:04.0000] <Hixie>
ap: why not?

[16:53:05.0000] <ap>
annevk2: by blocking send() until the queue is free? we agreed to never block

[16:53:06.0000] <Hixie>
franksalim: because people are going to ignore this data, and we don't want to make this UDP-like

[16:54:00.0000] <annevk2>
ap, it can queue up in the local RAM

[16:54:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: hmm, maybe it can be implemented, let me think

[16:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
annevk2: if you're calling send() faster than the network can handle, you'll eventually run out of RAM

[16:54:03.0000] <annevk2>
ap, and when there's OOM it's just like any other platform implementation

[16:54:04.0000] <franksalim>
there are many ways for a javascript application to eat arbitrarily large amounts of RAM if the author is careless or malicious

[16:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm rather with anne on this to be honest

[16:55:01.0000] <annevk2>
with implementation I meant limitation, sorry

[16:57:00.0000] <ap>
annevk2: e.g. if you're sending a video stream from a capture device, there is no good in filling up RAM until OOM

[16:57:01.0000] <ap>
annevk2: you want to be notified quickly, and to downscale your video

[16:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
we don't support sending a video stream

[16:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
if that's the use case, we can fix this in v2

[16:58:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: why don't we?

[16:58:02.0000] <annevk2>
I was just about to say that for specific types of data (e.g. files from the local disk) we should let send() accept dedicated types (e.g. FileData) and let the UA handle the specifics

[16:58:03.0000] <ap>
Hixie: what about an audio stream?

[16:58:04.0000] <annevk2>
it just handles text

[16:58:05.0000] <Hixie>
ap: because we don't have any of the building blocks for that yet

[16:59:00.0000] <ap>

[16:59:01.0000] <Hixie>

[16:59:02.0000] <ap>

[16:59:03.0000] <Hixie>

[17:01:01.0000] <ap>

[17:02:00.0000] <ap>
Hixie: so yes, send() can of course return how much space there's in UA queue at the moment (I was thinking about kernel queue, and this data is usually unavailable)

[17:02:01.0000] <ap>

[17:03:00.0000] <annevk2>

[17:03:01.0000] <annevk2>

[17:05:00.0000] <ap>

[17:05:01.0000] <ap>
or take 50% of available bandwidth, for example

[17:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok so i got run of onoverflow, and instead just made send() return a number, which is either 0 (connection closed), 1 (buffering not supported), a number indicating the number of bytes that can be buffered, or 4294967295 if the buffering is essentially unlimited.

[17:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
and overflowing the buffer closes the connection.

[17:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
got rid of, rather

[17:08:00.0000] <franksalim>
i'm catching up on the mailing list thread. has the alternative been discussed in which notification occurs when writes are successful? this would allow application code to make use of an arbitrarily large buffer but be aware of the rate at which the buffer is being drained

[17:08:01.0000] <ap>
Hixie: what is the client to do when 1 is returned?

[17:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
ap: pray it doesn't hit the network rate limit

[17:09:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:09:01.0000] <ap>

[17:09:02.0000] <ap>

[17:10:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
but yeah

[17:10:02.0000] <Hixie>

[17:10:03.0000] <ap>

[17:10:04.0000] <franksalim>
ap, successfully dequeued by the UA

[17:10:05.0000] <franksalim>

[17:11:00.0000] <ap>
franksalim: I see. I don't think it's been suggested

[17:11:01.0000] <franksalim>

[17:12:00.0000] <roc>
what was wrong with my idea of allowing apps to query the amount of buffered data?

[17:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
roc: that's basically what we have now, though in reverse

[17:12:02.0000] <franksalim>
most (all?) other js APIs can use arbitrarily large amounts of memory

[17:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
maybe we should also have an attribute for the actual amount pending?

[17:13:01.0000] <franksalim>

[17:13:02.0000] <ap>
franksalim: I think that a highwater mark notification would still be needed to rate limit

[17:13:03.0000] <Hixie>

[17:13:04.0000] <franksalim>
Hixie, but then you don't know how much of the buffer you have used

[17:13:05.0000] <Hixie>
franksalim: correct

[17:14:00.0000] <roc>

[17:14:01.0000] <franksalim>
i think it is desirable to have an unlimited buffer size with the ability to know how large a buffer you are using

[17:14:02.0000] <franksalim>

[17:14:03.0000] <Hixie>

[17:14:04.0000] <ap>
franksalim: "other js APIs can use arbitrarily large amounts of memory" - the issue here is not with OOM, but with letting the app achieve its mission. other JS APIs don't usually cause infinite memory growth when doing something useful

[17:15:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:15:01.0000] <franksalim>
ap, yes. but setting a max buffer size is not necessary. the important data is how far backed up you are, not how much space you have left

[17:15:03.0000] <roc>

[17:15:04.0000] <ap>

[17:18:01.0000] <Hixie>

[17:19:00.0000] <Hixie>

[06:10:01.0000] <Lachy>

[06:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
Dashiva, Hixie claims it's because of situations like <img alt= class=photo> where "class=photo" would be interpreted as the value of the alt attribute

[06:27:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:27:01.0000] <Lachy>

[06:27:02.0000] <Lachy>

[06:28:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:28:01.0000] <Lachy>

[06:28:02.0000] <Lachy>
yes

[06:38:00.0000] <Philip`>

[06:39:00.0000] <Philip`>

[06:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, you could use a rough technique by looking for obvious cases like the href attribute where = in values is common <a href= ?foo-bar>, and also look for [^=]+=\s+([A-Za-z]+)= where $1 matches known attribute names

[06:42:01.0000] <Lachy>
s/foo-bar/foo=bar/

[06:43:00.0000] <Lachy>
actually, just the regex would be more like [A-Za-z]+=\s+([A-Za-z]+)=

[06:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
or [A-Za-z]+\s?=\s+([A-Za-z]+)=

[08:40:00.0000] <ezyang>
Does HTML5 do anything special to &image inside URLs? 

[08:41:00.0000] <gsnedders>
ezyang: no

[08:41:01.0000] <ezyang>
hmm, ok 

[08:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
&image; is special, though

[08:46:00.0000] <ezyang>
oh, wow, so browsers will interpret &image= as the actual character entity. News to me. 

[08:46:01.0000] <Philip`>
No, only &image;=

[08:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Well, or &image;foo or whatever)

[08:47:01.0000] <ezyang>
Wait, really? 

[08:48:00.0000] <ezyang>
If the character reference is being consumed as part of an attribute, and the last character matched is not a U+003B SEMICOLON (;), and the next character is in the range U+0030 DIGIT ZERO to U+0039 DIGIT NINE, U+0041 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A to U+005A LATIN CAPITAL LETTER Z, or U+0061 LATIN SMALL LETTER A to U+007A LATIN SMALL LETTER Z, then, for historical reasons, all the characters that were matched after the U+0026 AMPERSAND (&) must be unconsumed, 

[08:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
Only the ones explicitly listed (in the giant table in HTML5) without a semicolon will be parsed if they don't have a semicolon

[08:48:02.0000] <ezyang>
aha! 

[08:48:03.0000] <Philip`>
and then only in cases where they're not followed by 0-9a-z

[08:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
so &amp=foo is an entity, &ampx=foo isn't, &image=foo isn't, &image;=foo is

[08:49:01.0000] <Philip`>
(if I remember correctly)

[08:49:02.0000] <Philip`>
(in attribute values)

[10:31:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:32:00.0000] <jacobolus>

[10:33:00.0000] <takkaria>

[10:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
(?i)font(?:-family)?\s*:([^;"}]+) gives some stuff you could extract individual names from

[10:38:00.0000] <jacobolus>
Philip`: will your regexps just return all captures?

[10:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
jacobolus: For each line that matches the regexp, it can either print the line or print the first matching substring or print any captured group

[10:40:00.0000] <jacobolus>
just one of the captured groups?

[10:40:01.0000] <jacobolus>
oh, I guess if it can print the lines out, it would be possible to grab that and run further regexps on it

[10:40:02.0000] <Philip`>
Yes

[10:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
Most of the lines have lots of HTML junk in them

[10:46:00.0000] <jacobolus>
yeah

[10:46:01.0000] <Philip`>
jacobolus: http://philip.html5.org/data/fonts-in-inline-css-raw.txt.gz (~7MB) has the strings that match the regexp I gave earlier

[10:47:00.0000] <jacobolus>
font(?:\-family)?\s*\:.*\s*((?:(?:'[a-zA-Z ]*')|(?:"[a-zA-Z ]*")|[a-zA-Z]*)(?=\s*[,}])[^}]*)}

[10:47:01.0000] <Philip`>
(I can do it differently if you're willing to wait ten minutes for it to regenerate)

[10:47:02.0000] <jacobolus>
I think that should be right

[10:47:03.0000] <jacobolus>
I should do some testing

[10:47:04.0000] <Philip`>
(Use a command like 'gzip -cd fonts-in-inline-css-raw.txt.gz|sort -u|cut -f2|sort|uniq -c|sort -n' to count number of pages each string occurs on, etc)

[10:49:00.0000] <jacobolus>
actually

[10:49:01.0000] <jacobolus>
font(?:\-family)?\s*\:.*\s*((?:(?:'[a-zA-Z ]*')|(?:"[a-zA-Z ]*")|[a-zA-Z]*)(?=\s*[,;}])[^;}]*)[};]

[10:49:02.0000] <Philip`>

[15:39:00.0000] <Philip`>

[16:09:00.0000] <tantek>
in lieu of an email writeup in lieu of a wiki writeup (probably to follow at some point) :

[16:09:01.0000] <tantek>
While the HTML 4.01 definition of CITE

[16:09:02.0000] <tantek>
http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/text.html#edef-CITE

[16:09:03.0000] <tantek>
"Contains a citation or a reference to other sources"

[16:09:04.0000] <tantek>
may be too vague, 

[16:09:05.0000] <tantek>
the current HTML5 draft definition:

[16:09:06.0000] <tantek>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/text-level-semantics.html#the-cite-element

[16:09:07.0000] <tantek>
"The cite element represents the title of a work..."

[16:09:08.0000] <tantek>
"A person's name is not the title of a work ..."

[16:09:09.0000] <tantek>
is a bit too narrow.

[16:10:00.0000] <tantek>
The cite element is for *any* kind of source, whether that source is:

[16:10:01.0000] <tantek>
* the title of a printed work, or 

[16:10:02.0000] <tantek>
* a URL to an online work (should be represented by a nested hyperlink), 

[16:10:03.0000] <tantek>
* or even the name of a person who said something, perhaps outloud in person or in an online chat such as IRC.

[16:10:04.0000] <Hixie>
why people?

[16:10:05.0000] <tantek>
Note that I am not advocating allowing marking up the name of an author of a work with cite, but rather, when the source/work is simply speech from an author that is not otherwise part of a work, then it is appropriate to markup the author (and their name or online nickname) as a cite.

[16:10:06.0000] <Hixie>
using <cite> for names is silly

[16:10:07.0000] <Hixie>
it's typographically wrong

[16:10:08.0000] <Hixie>
it's applying semantics where none are needed

[16:10:09.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, do you have a reference for why/how it is *typographically* wrong?

[16:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
sure, hold on

[16:11:01.0000] <tantek>
The precise semantic is that the *person* themsevles is the "other source".

[16:11:02.0000] <tantek>
when quoting from otherwise untitled/ungrouped speech from that person

[16:12:00.0000] <tantek>
thus the person themselves is the "other source" (per HTML 4.01 definition)

[16:12:01.0000] <tantek>
hence the usage of cite to refer to a speaker in such examples is semantically correct

[16:13:00.0000] <tantek>
(oops sorry about the nearly dup text there)

[16:15:00.0000] <tantek>
and also note that I am not advocating for general use of <cite> for names.

[16:18:00.0000] <tantek>
but rather for a very specific use for a person's name (or nickname if appropriate, e.g. for quoting from IRC) saying something which is quoted.

[16:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
my reference for the typography of names is going to be the chicacgo manual of style. I can't find anything in there that justifies using the same element for a title of a work and a name of a person, ever.

[16:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
<cite> is not for citations at all in html5

[16:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's just for titles of works

[16:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
because that's more useful in practice as far as i can tell

[16:43:00.0000] <annevk2>
/me thought the answer to http://twitter.com/johnfoliot/statuses/2918355573 has been long known

[16:43:01.0000] <annevk2>
/me wonders what this new wave of fake-ignorance is about

[16:44:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, in practice <cite> is also useful for names of speakers as noted above. E.g. http://rbach.priv.at/Microformats/IRC/2009-05-01

[16:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: how is it useful there?

[16:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: just use <dt> and <dialog> for a chat log.

[16:45:02.0000] <tantek>
the same as knowing what the "source" is for any quottation

[16:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
knowing what the "source" is for any quotation is not useful, as far as i can tell

[16:45:04.0000] <Hixie>
sounds useful

[16:45:05.0000] <Hixie>
but is not actually useful

[16:46:00.0000] <tantek>
it is useful, in that it provides a mechanism by which it may be possible to determine the validity of the quote

[16:46:01.0000] <tantek>
often by looking up the source

[16:46:02.0000] <Hixie>
you don't need an element for that

[16:46:03.0000] <tantek>
the same usefulness for citing any source

[16:46:04.0000] <Hixie>
what's the use for the element that can't be done without any element?

[16:46:05.0000] <tantek>
what is the harm in permitting an existing semantic usage to continue?

[16:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's _exactly_ what the spec is doing

[16:47:01.0000] <tantek>
I believe there is more weight on the side of keeping an existing practical usage, than dropping it. It doesn't appear to be doing any harm.

[16:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
the existing semantic usage is people use it for titles

[16:47:03.0000] <Hixie>
not citations

[16:47:04.0000] <tantek>
No the current draft spec is keeping one usage and dropping another.

[16:49:00.0000] <tantek>
people are using <cite> to refer to "other sources" per HTML 4.01.  *one* of those other sources is the title of a work, another is a URL to a work, yet another is the name of a speaker of a quote. all of which are sources.

[16:50:00.0000] <tantek>
I understand the utility in refining the definition as given in HTML 4.01. However it seems to do more harm than good to ignore one of those existing uses, and disallow another, rather than explicitly allow all three existing uses.

[16:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
the vast majority of people who are using <cite> for any purpose other than "italics" are using <cite> to mean "title of work", not "cited name"

[16:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
and there is no good use for using it to mark up cited names that needs an element

[16:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
using it for names has one harm, it encourages people to use incorrect typography for names

[16:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
just look at anne's blog

[16:51:03.0000] <tantek>
Is Anne using it incorrectly?

[16:51:04.0000] <Hixie>
he's using it as you suggest

[16:52:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, it's not clear that "no good use for it" argument makes any sense, as any use case for the "title of a work" can also be made for the name of a speaker 

[16:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
the only use case for title of work is "makes it italics", which doesn't apply to "name of a speaker"

[16:53:01.0000] <tantek>
I disagree - another use of the title of a work, and name of a speaker, is to look up said title/name and provide more information

[16:53:02.0000] <tantek>
about the source

[16:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
you don't need an element to do that

[16:54:00.0000] <tantek>
you do - in order to indicate what is the title or name of the speaker, as opposed to nearby text

[16:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
So if I say "Tantek said that you needed that", you wouldn't know that "Tantek" was a name, because I didn't mark it up?

[16:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
either i'm dramatically misunderstanding you, or someone gave you semantic web drugs this morning

[16:55:01.0000] <tantek>
entity discovery/resolution is buggy/unreliable, even in just one language, nevermind internationally.

[16:55:02.0000] <annevk2>
I stopped using <cite> that way btw

[16:55:03.0000] <tantek>
with the exception of very well defined text grammar

[16:55:04.0000] <Hixie>
people have no trouble understanding what is a name and what isn't

[16:55:05.0000] <tantek>
Hixie - depends on the language

[16:55:06.0000] <Hixie>
no, it really doesn't

[16:56:00.0000] <tantek>
and what about names that are not title-cased?

[16:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
like when i say that tantek said something?

[16:56:02.0000] <tantek>
Hixie - right

[16:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
you have no problem seeing the name there either

[16:56:04.0000] <tantek>
assuming you have a NLP that processes the sentence at all

[16:56:05.0000] <Hixie>
if you really, really, truly and honestly really desperately need some sort o machine-readable way to know that something is a name... use hCard

[16:56:06.0000] <tantek>
is the name "that tantek" or "tantek"

[16:58:00.0000] <tantek>
it gets more complicated in languages such as German where all nouns are capitalized

[16:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
please show me one example of that confusion actually happening, where <cite> would actually have helped.

[16:58:02.0000] <tantek>
Hixie - agreed that hCard helps to markup the name of a person and recognize it as such, especially if it has several name components (given, family, suffix etc.)

[16:59:00.0000] <tantek>
what <cite> does above and beyond that, is to indicate that that person is a *source*

[16:59:01.0000] <tantek>
which can then be connected to a quotation q through its cite attribute

[16:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
in html5, <cite> doesn't indicate that the thing is a source

[16:59:03.0000] <Hixie>
ok come now, nobody ever uses cite=""

[16:59:04.0000] <annevk2>
the main problem with using <cite> for this is, as I learned after I used it for a while, is that it is typographically incorrect, at least in English, to italicize the name

[16:59:05.0000] <Hixie>
i've seriously considered dropping cite="" altogether


2009-07-30
[17:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
precisely to stop this kind of argument :-)

[17:00:01.0000] <annevk2>
Hixie, I use that!

[17:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
no, you don't. As an author you do, but not as a user.

[17:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
and as an author i bet it's never done you one iota of good.

[17:00:04.0000] <tantek>
e.g. <cite id="qs01">tantek</cite> said <q cite="#qs01">which can be connected to a quotation q through its cite attribute</q>

[17:00:05.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: you don't need any markup whatsoever for that. Just write tantek said "which can be connected to a quotation q through its cite attribute

[17:00:06.0000] <Hixie>
"

[17:00:07.0000] <ttepasse>
annevk2, how is that a problem? In a non-CSS-world - but where ist such a thing?

[17:01:00.0000] <annevk2>
Hixie, I have some script that displays it to the user

[17:01:01.0000] <annevk2>

[17:01:02.0000] <ttepasse>

[17:01:03.0000] <annevk2>

[17:02:01.0000] <annevk2>

[17:03:00.0000] <ttepasse>

[17:03:01.0000] <annevk2>

[17:04:00.0000] <annevk2>
ttepasse, my text editor is akin to notepad / <textarea>

[17:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
so, anyone want to volunteer to write a script that scans the spec to generate these tables? :-) http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#index

[17:21:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, your point about "don't need any markup ... for that" again depends on NLP/entity-recognition, which as noted, is non-trivial in one language, let alone internationally.

[17:21:01.0000] <tantek>
Regarding the harm "incorrect typography for names" - I will accept that issue and get back to you with appropriate default style sheet rules.

[17:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
humans are good at NLP

[17:21:03.0000] <Hixie>
very good

[17:22:00.0000] <tantek>
Regarding "show me one example of that confusion actually happening, where <cite> would actually have helped." I will research and provide more examples.

[17:23:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, semantic markup is for UAs to present better user interfaces though right? If all we needed was to present things for humans, plain text with appropriate whitespace would be sufficient for many/most use cases.

[17:24:00.0000] <rubys>
Hixie: my experience is otherwise.

[17:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: i'm not convinced there's any need for better UI for users to work out who is saying what, to be honest.

[17:24:02.0000] <tantek>
Anyway - your request for more examples is certainly very reasonable.

[17:24:03.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, as a sample UI, being able to right-click on a source and get info on it/them.

[17:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
who does that? that's a dream of Semantic Web people that in my experience "normal" users don't share

[17:25:01.0000] <tantek>
Indeed in Mozilla (and perhaps Opera?) I believe it was/is possible to right click on a q/blockquote and get the cite attribute(d) source.

[17:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
rubys: literacy rates might be better in europe :-)

[17:26:00.0000] <tantek>
from there, when that cite attribute links (through a frag id as shown in the example above) to a <cite> element, then that can provide further information

[17:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
i encourage you to consider what real problem users are facing would be addressed by this, rather than what theoretical problems might be addressed by this

[17:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
i've never, ever, ever heard a user say "i wish i could figure out who wrote that quote... maybe if i right-click on it it will highlight the name of the author for me"

[17:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
i have heard them say things like "i wish i could read my web mail while on a plane without network connectivity"

[17:28:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, one real world usage is Wikipedia, where quotes/assertions are cited, and hyperlinks are used to create a UI from quote/assertion to source etc.

[17:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
what's wrong with what they do now?

[17:29:00.0000] <tantek>
nothing, in the same way that <br><br> was sufficient to indicate paragraphs. but now just as we have the <p> element for semantically marking up paragraphs so that we can avoid "hacking" a presentational paragraph, it makes sense to *keep* the cite attribute / cite element to semantically markup citations and sources

[17:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
<p> gives true styling benefits

[17:30:01.0000] <tantek>
and "heard them say" is not the best way of interpreting user needs. watching/analyzing user behaviors (e.g. in content publishing) is often better than simply listening to what they say they think they need.

[17:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
if your proposed variant of <cite> solves real problems, this would change my reaction, but currently i'm not aware of any real problems that would be solved by making <cite> cover citing names of people

[17:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: totally agreed re: user needs

[17:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
tantek: i've never seen a usability study where anything like citations on quoted has come up

[17:31:03.0000] <tantek>
hence I mentioned content publishing behavior

[17:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
(and i've seen a lot of them, i'm on google's usability lab access list so that i can keep an eye on this very kind of thing)

[17:32:01.0000] <tantek>
user studies may be sufficient, but are not necessarily necessary to make such a case

[17:38:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, while I'm not sure I can necessarily meet your threshold for what you call a "real" problem, I'm fairly certain I can provide real world use cases with examples, and I'll at least do that.

[17:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
cool, that would certainly help

[17:40:00.0000] <tantek>
I think with sufficient real world use cases (with examples), at some point the advantage of keeping functionality which is allowed by (the admittedly ambiguously broad) wording of the existing HTML 4.01 spec is greater than the minor advantage of simplification/reduction that you gain by removing/dropping that functionality.

[17:40:01.0000] <tantek>
I understand that is a judgment call, and that reasonable people can come to different conclusions based on similar facts on such a point.

[17:40:02.0000] <tantek>
I hope by providing more data I can narrow any such gaps in conclusions at least a bit.

[17:43:00.0000] <tantek>
And for that matter, let me just say that I do commend your general effort at simplification/reduction, lest that is not clear by the arguments I've made above.

[17:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
fwiw, what html4 says has no bearing on what html5 says -- i only base the spec on legacy content and legacy UAs, not legacy specs.

[17:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
and don't worry, i don't take any offence at all from our discussions, i know your heart is in the same place as mine :-)

[17:45:00.0000] <tantek>
understood. I'm looking at the legacy content part of that, which, often reflects what html4.01 says, especially as interpreted by the broader web design / semantic HTML community.

[17:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
the broader web design / semantic HTML community is sadly a tiny minority of the wider web :-(

[17:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
from what i've seen, <cite> is almost always used to mean "italics"

[17:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
i'm willing to ignore that on the basis that that was never a valid use

[17:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
never even remotely a valid use

[17:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
i agree that some people mark up names using <cite>, as well as marking up titles, and some people (me, circa 2004) go out of their way to only mark up citations with <cite>

[17:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
so there is definitely use to back up all of these options

[17:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
this leaves the question of what is the most useful use we can put the element to

[17:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
and my conclusion so far is that the most useful use for <cite> is as an element to allow typographic control over titles, since those are often made italics

[17:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
and generally, names and titles aren't typeset the same way, so i am reluctant to make the element apply to both

[17:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
especially since we have so many ways of marking up names already (e.g. hCard, microdata vCard, RDFa vCard, etc)

[12:58:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
annevk: About packages. It may be better to supply it as an alternative download for compatibility. <img src="file.jpg" psrc="archive.tgz#file.jpg" /> { background-image: url(file.jpg); background-image: purl(archive.tgz#file.jpg); } I don't think it needs it's own protocol/scheme.

[13:04:00.0000] <annevk>
well, dunno if they're really needed (see HTTP pipelining which would be much neater) and that syntax does not solve the issue I raised

[13:11:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
annevk: HTTP pipelining needs major fixes to make that viable. Timeout issues for servers, broken servers, broken proxies... And you don't get the added benefit of compressing the traffic as a unit.

[13:12:00.0000] <annevk>
is that a major benefit?

[13:12:01.0000] <sebmarkbage>
What issue did you raise? Fragment identifiers? The multipart, tar, etc. already has identifiers.

[13:12:02.0000] <annevk>
yes, fragment identifiers

[13:14:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
On text data, at least, it's a major benefit to compress multiple small parts as a single unit. Hence .tar.gz and not .gz.tar

[13:19:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
annevk: As I see it, there's nothing in the URI specs that would prevent one from using the fragment to identify a part of a multipart document. Of course it needs to be speced. But there's no need to define an additional protocol or URI scheme.

[13:24:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
rfc2854 for text/html, rfc5147 for text/plain, rfcXXXX for multipart/mixed

[13:42:00.0000] <annevk>
sebmarkbage, the issue is how I'd use a fragment identifier for the document then

[13:48:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
annevk: Well that would depend on the format chosen. application/tar obviously has filenames. multipart/form-data has a name attribute in Content-Disposition. multipart/related has Content-ID...

[13:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
annevk: Are you able to SSH to Dreamhost? (I get "ssh_exchange_identification: Connection closed by remote host" whenever I try on hobgoblin)

[13:57:00.0000] <annevk>
me too

[13:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
Okay

[14:00:00.0000] <annevk>
sebmarkbage, then it doesn't work

[14:01:00.0000] <annevk>
Philip`, not sure why it doesn't work

[14:02:00.0000] <annevk>
Philip`, if it still doesn't tomorrow I'll ask DreamHost

[14:02:01.0000] <annevk>
(unless you're in a hurry then I can do it in a few minutes)

[14:02:02.0000] <sebmarkbage>
annevk, if one format is chosen as a standard for something like psrc, I don't see why. All the parts are already there. All you'd have to do is specify how the fragment part is suppose to be handled for mime type: multipart/x

[14:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
annevk: No hurry :-)

[14:07:00.0000] <annevk>
sebmarkbage, say for an SVG file I need to use a fragment identifier to get a particular effect; as in /example.svg#view... (forgot the syntax); how do I express that if example.svg is packaged?

[14:12:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
annevk, rfc3986 (generic uri) allows for the possibility of multiple #, so: /archive.tgz#example.svg#view...

[14:13:00.0000] <sebmarkbage>
if the particular format chosen allows for # in the identifier, I guess it'd be encoded

[03:14:04.0000] <othermaciej>
the XML version is more reliable but completely separate

[03:14:05.0000] <mookid>
=)

[03:14:06.0000] <othermaciej>
microdata would let you parse the HTML and reliably extract data in the face of markup changes

[03:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
Microdata would make the extracted data extremely fragile because it would keep breaking whenever someone changed the markup and forgot to check the microdata was identical in all cases

[03:15:01.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: But why not use the XML interface?

[03:15:02.0000] <othermaciej>
though in general consumers will intend to work with bugzilla specifically and don't need a generic central "bug database" vocabulary

[03:15:03.0000] <mookid>
or you could negotiate content and use a more appropriate format than HTML for data interchange? :D

[03:15:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:16:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[03:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:17:02.0000] <mookid>

[03:18:01.0000] <mookid>

[09:19:00.0000] <cgriego>
annevk: I think legend would be an excellent element to use with figure and details, except every major browser has issues with it, and not because they did anything wrong. HTML 4 defines legend, as a form element, to be a replaced element. Undoing that is a radical change in definition.

[09:26:00.0000] <annevk>
I don't think HTML4 defined it as such

[09:26:01.0000] <adactio>
cgriego: I agree. I tried to some DOM Scripting with <details> and it proved to be impossible because of the way that browsers interpret the presence of the <legend> element (Safari throws it away, Firefox generates a <fieldset>).

[09:26:02.0000] <adactio>
The problem is ...what's the alternative?

[09:27:00.0000] <annevk>
(in theory it should be treated as an unknown element outside of <fieldset>)

[09:27:01.0000] <annevk>
to elaborate a little bit, one of the other goals we have is keeping the language simple

[09:27:02.0000] <annevk>
and as browsers fix their bugs <legend> will become useful

[09:28:00.0000] <annevk>
it might take a little longer, but not having to introduce a new element seems worth it

[09:28:01.0000] <adactio>
annevk: I agree and I think that Safari and Firefox will probably fix this pretty quickly but IE (again) is going to really slow things down.

[09:29:00.0000] <adactio>
I've read through the arguments for and against <legend>: http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2008-February/014038.html

[09:29:01.0000] <adactio>
And I agree, in principle, that it's far more preferable to "recycle" an existing element than to create a new one.

[09:30:00.0000] <adactio>
But I'd really like to be able to use the new HTML5 elements and as long as some of them use <legend>, they're effectively out of bounds. :-(

[09:32:00.0000] <adactio>
Remy has a more detailed breakdown of the issues: http://html5doctor.com/legend-not-such-a-legend-anymore/
